"The story does not worth it. Gameplaywise, its a walking simulator with one type of puzzle repeated over and over again throughout the whole game. Its really repetitive. The sections when you just walk arent that exciting because of how slow the main character is, the map is usually ultra-linear, but there are specific parts of the game with a lot of passageways and if you get lost, it becomes really stressful how slow the mobility is."

Thats an extract of my Hellblade: Senua's Sacrifice review. On the other hand, if we're talking about video games set in norse mythology in which you have a head hanging from your waist, God of War (2018) is the better game. God of War (2018) in fact is an amazing game. Really good and smooth gameplay, amazing writing, charming characters and villains, really good lore. This game in my opinion is the whole package. It can offer you super good boss fights that need real skill to overcome, and it can also give you incredible cutscenes with a mind-blowing emotional weight that can make you cry. Much more so if you played the original trilogy, as I did. I love the evolution of Kratos as a character and I love this father-son story set in a world as interesting as midgard. I'm very happy to be able to enjoy this game on steam, I'm very excited for the inevitable release of God of War Ragnarok on pc. Hope its soon. It's not a perfect game, nor is it a perfect port. But as a whole, it's totally worth it. Really recommend this one!
This game was amazing! The minute I finished I booted up my PS4 to play God of War: Ragnarök.

GREAT GAME LOVE IT AND SO WILL YOU IF YOU'RE COOL!!!!!

I haven't finished the game yet, if I had to guess I'd say I am around halfway through the main story or so.

First of all, I didn't play any God of War games past the PS2 a decent few years ago. I watched a recap of GOW1-3's story before playing just to get my brain right towards the game's setting.. but surprised to see that from Greek Mythology we went into Norse Mythology! Which is also probably the most interesting mythology in my opinion.

So firstly the game is challenging. I am playing through the "Give me challenge" difficulty which is almost the hardest difficulty to pick up. The gameplay is VERY fun and in the past 2 weeks I probably was quite addicted to this game. 
On the other hand, I was blown from the fact GOW (well, at least this one, I can't really recall for the older titles) is very story rich. And the story is realllly good and interesting. I am literally wanting to see more every second of it and it keeps me on my toes. It's a lot more interesting if you have interest in the Norse Mythology as well! 

The attention to detail in this game is also solid. The level design is fucking mind blowing. There are those small things that you encounter in this game and it's just things you know you will only encounter in a god of war game. One of the MSQ level design got me really impressed. To keep it as spoiler-free as possible (skip this next 2 sentences if you want to ignore a minor level design spoiler) 

----------SLIGHT LEVEL DESIGN STORY SPOILER ------- a whole level is based on top and around a giant's dead frozen body. A real fucking giant. And it's HUGE. This giant also has facial hair (you literally walk past it's head) and it's fucking blowing in the wind. not to mention this giant also has NOSE HAIR. AND IT'S BLOWING IN THE WIND AS WELL. The attention to detail is just.. incredible in the level design.
------------ SPOILER END ---------

The graphics are reallly good. The atmosphere and the visuals are stunning. The gameplay is fun, challenging and addicting. And the performance is great, I always have high frames and no stutters/drops. Although, sadly the game did crash twice for me in 21h of playtime, but twice in 21h is acceptable. At least it wasn't during an intense boss battle or a cutscene!

Overall, I'd really recommend trying this game. The hack n' slash combat is solid, theres a good sense of progression and you can easily find challenge around the game. There are a lot of mysteries to resolve, side quests, collectibles and whatnot. I can't say for certain, but getting this game to 100% completion is for sure gonna take a while, I'm just around halfway through the game and I feel like I missed out a lot of side content that I'd have to go back and experience.

PLUS - the game is kind off open world? well, it is very open and you can basically go back to any point you visited during the game, and there is a some sort of fast travel you unlock sometime after the early game, AND there are 0 loading screens in-between. It's VERY open and the world is very big but I wouldn't call it a true open world game. Some areas are also locked behind mechanics which are unlocked later on the story.

Anyways - this is a great game. Highly addictive, fun and challenging. Definitely a 9/10 from me. for the most parts, I could not stop playing.
And for everyone who wonders why I gave it a 9/10 and not 10/10, it's because while the story is really good, rich and interesting (and long), the voice acting can be a little bit off sometimes, characters can repeat sentences in a robotic way at certain times, Kratos's running animation is a bit wonky and the movement animations could use a bit of a polish.
I am 100% certain this is intended, but whoever voiced Kratos is just.. I can't even explain it. You gotta play to understand. Great game.

[h1]8/10[/h1] This game is presented beautifully. Everything from animations, cutscenes, enemy and character designs. Probably one of the most polished games I've played. Once the awe wears off you will start seeing its flaws.

The relationship between Kratos and Atreus is well done, the whole thing with Baldur and his mom felt like an afterthought. Most of the side characters were pretty interesting though. Some parts of the game, like when going into Jörmungandr's stomach, felt like a way to make the game longer without really adding anything.

Enemy variety is lacking. There is like 10 enemy archetypes and then those can be either fiery or icy. This is not enough for a game of this length. Boss fights are scarce and disappointing, although they have cool set pieces and epic moments.
 
Nifelheim, Muspelheim and the Valkyries are a giant pain in the ass. You have to put in a lot of effort for mostly copy and paste loot with a few unique armor pieces here and there. Honestly these extra locations actually detract from the main game.

The exploration and puzzles were simple but effective. The puzzles were very formulaic and this became very tedious after a while. The platforming and traversal are extremely basic and uninteresting.

The combat is simple, satisfying. Nothing too special. The "Glory Kills" that you can perform when enemies are stunned have little variety, they only seem to change depending on the enemy being either a standard unit or a fire bender etc., which is strange. Bigger enemies suffer from the same issue. Didn't care much for the armour and crafting system.

You can see why this game was big when it came out. It appeals to a wide audience and has enough depth for casual gamers to enjoy.

Minor Issues: Manual saves don't work. Camera is placed in a way that maximizes cinematography but hinders gameplay. After the end of the game Atreus will not shut up and repeats the same line over and over.

This game is amazing, the story is one of the best I've ever experienced, and the game-play is really good, the only real fault i could give it is that the controls never really clicked for me but i did play it on mouse and keyboard.

This was disappointing. From start to finish the game tries to tell you this emotional story of a father, son and mother, yet if falls flat. The biggest issues I have with God of War is the poor writing and the lack of player motivation.

First off, the writing: The narrative likes to drop new conflicts and whatnot into the story and tosses it out as quickly as it was introduced. One example was in the very beginning: While exploring, your son Artreus asks how it is to kill a person and Kratos, your character, explains that killing is part of surviving. “Close your heart” Kratos says. Fast forward five minutes and in a battle, Artreus kills a person. He is visibly shocked and feeling down. Not even a minute passes and this entire shtick is tossed out the window, never to be brought back again. There are plenty of these moments, where some sort of obstacle is presented for both Kratos and Artreus only for it to be discarded minutes later. And with this the pacing also feels very off. Everything moves too fast. Conflicts aren’t real. They are only here to give you the illusion of conflict. They might as well remove them and it would still play out the same.

Now the motivation part is a bit difficult to explain but I try my best: The groups entire motivation for this game’s story is to scatter the ashes of Kratos’ deceased wife on the peak of the highest mountain. It is after all her last wish. Who is this wife? I don’t know. And the game doesn’t tell me either. I understand that Kratos, her husband, and Artreus, her son, want to honor her wish. But me? The player? This isn’t a movie where I watch the characters do what they do. I am in direct control. Both the characters and me should share the same motivation. But I couldn’t care less about this woman. I never even get to see her, so why should I care.

The gameplay is a mixed bag. Combat is serviceable at best. First off, the camera is way to close to your character. It feels more like a third person shooter. Spatial awareness is thus gone. But I feel the developers knew this and added an indicator at the bottom, warning you if an enemy is behind you or if it is attacking. With this the combat becomes laughably easy. Beat an enemy until one of those indicators turn red, turn around by 180° and block. Rinse and repeat. It feels claustrophobic and all threat is gone. The game is a button masher with no real strategy or depth. The charged axe attack, you can unlock pretty much from the beginning, allows you to deal massive damage to a single normal sized target and cause it to stay limp on the floor for a short time. But enough time for you to run towards him and do the same charged attack again. The game also has RPG elements, such as enemy levels and gear levels. They could’ve just skipped those. Not every game needs to play like an action-RPG.

Graphics and sound are good. No complains here. Music isn’t anything special, but that’s just me.

God of War (2022) is nothing short of a masterpiece, a game that transcends the boundaries of its genre to deliver an unforgettable experience. Santa Monica Studio has not only revived Kratos but has also reinvented the entire God of War franchise, giving players a deeply emotional and compelling journey that stands out as one of the finest in gaming history.

The narrative takes center stage, weaving a poignant tale of fatherhood, redemption, and the consequences of one's past actions. Kratos, once a rage-fueled Spartan seeking vengeance, now finds himself in the world of Norse mythology, accompanied by his son Atreus. The dynamic between father and son forms the heart of the story, creating a bond that is as vulnerable as it is powerful.

Graphically, God of War is a visual spectacle. The attention to detail in the character models, environments, and cinematic sequences is breathtaking. From the mythical landscapes of Midgard to the intimidating creatures that inhabit it, every aspect of the game is a testament to the capabilities of modern gaming technology.

The combat system is a perfect blend of visceral action and strategic depth. Kratos' Leviathan Axe is not only a devastating weapon but also a versatile tool that can be thrown and recalled with precision. The integration of Atreus into combat adds an extra layer of strategy, as players can command him to shoot arrows, providing crowd control and setting up combos.

Exploration is encouraged, and the world of God of War is rich with lore, hidden secrets, and challenging puzzles. The game seamlessly combines a linear narrative with open-world elements, offering a balance that keeps players engaged without feeling overwhelmed.

The soundtrack, composed by Bear McCreary, complements the game's emotional beats perfectly. From haunting melodies to powerful orchestral compositions, the music enhances every moment, drawing players deeper into the world of God of War.

One of the most commendable aspects of the game is its single-shot camera style, a technical marvel that adds a cinematic quality to the entire experience. The continuous shot creates a sense of immersion, eliminating loading screens and maintaining a seamless flow from one scene to the next.

God of War (2022) is a triumph on all fronts, a game that pushes the boundaries of storytelling, gameplay mechanics, and technical achievement. It stands as a shining example of what the video game medium is capable of when approached with passion, creativity, and a commitment to excellence. Santa Monica Studio has not only redefined the God of War series but has set a new standard for the industry as a whole. This is not just a game; it's an epic journey that will resonate with players for years to come.

God of War 2018 is a masterpiece of gaming that blends action, story, and technology in a stunning and immersive way. It is a game that takes you on an epic journey through a rich and believable Norse world, where you play as Kratos, a former Greek god who has to protect and bond with his son, Atreus. The game has a diverse and satisfying combat system that lets you use a variety of weapons, skills, and strategies to defeat your enemies. The game also has a seamless and cinematic presentation that never breaks the immersion or the emotion of the story. The game is not only a visual marvel, but also a sonic and narrative wonder that creates a realistic and atmospheric experience. God of War 2018 is a game that I love and enjoy, and I think anyone who likes action, adventure, and mythology games should play it.

I always measure a video game by how it makes me feel after the sessions I spend playing through the game. Very rarely do I run into games where after I play, I not only crave for more of the experience, but I feel completely satisfied that my time was worth spending experiencing a game's world, lore, and characters. God of War (2018) is not just a video game, it is a cinematic experience that can seamlessly transition between video game and cinema.

The cinema aspect comes from the game's story about a father (Kratos) and his son (Atreus) and their journey to spread their mother's ashes on top of the highest peak in all the realms. It’s a story about parenting, and how Kratos and Atreus learn to become better people in wake of the mother’s passing. Kratos learns to become a better father for Atreus, and also for himself to be a bigger person than the murderous enraged wrecking ball he used to be in the previous games. Atreus learns to become a man through Kratos’s teachings and experience, slowly getting stronger and stronger as his learns from mistake after mistake. Kratos and Atreus’s personal journey is brilliantly contrasted by the game’s main antagonist, Baldur. For a great explanation on why Baldur is such a great villain in this game, I would recommend checking out this YouTube video by FatBrett. He makes great analysis videos on the characters within this game and its sequel, Ragnarok: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=s9vSCABh1K8

Speaking of Kratos, this game is technically the 4th entry in the God of War series. Despite this, I went into this game without any knowledge of God of War, and I followed along with the story and characters easily. Halfway through the game, I realized that anyone could pick up this game and easily understand what was going on without any prior knowledge of Kratos or other characters. If that turned you off from picking up this game, I can assure you you’re only robbing yourself from an unforgettable experience by delaying your purchase of this game (No, this review isn’t sponsored).

The gameplay is akin to hack-and-slash RPGs such as the first two Kingdom Hearts games and Dark Souls, and gives the traditional hack-and-slash game genre a more cinematic flare with its dynamic camera angles and fluid controls. The game also has a great amount of optional exploration involved, where if you’re willing to sink even more hours into this game, you will be greatly rewarded with upgrades and weapons that’ll help you with late game enemies and bosses.

In my opinion, I would not classify this as a game. Rather, I’d classify God of War as an ‘experience’. It easily makes my Top 5 video games of all time, and I would highly recommend it to anyone interested in a single-player experience they’re willing to drown hours upon hours of time.

A really enjoyable game from the start although it takes awhile to get into the flow of things but once you start to rank up you will find it a lot easier to take on multiple enemies, there are some real challenges along the way and that makes this game more than just a walk through and as you progress towards the later stages of the game it starts to get difficult again. The visuals are truly fantastic at some points and it really shows what the latest hardware is capable of when using DLSS and FSR, the soundtrack could have been better by adding Norse music or something similar its a bit disappointing compared to the rest of the game. An intriguing story that continues throughout the game and provides some interesting insights about the continuing story line of the 'God of war' series. Action packed with great atmosphere although a bit repetitive at times, in terms of games it is a masterpiece because it gets 9.5/10 for visuals and 9/10 for game play and 9/10 for story content and just lacks slightly 6/10 for sounds.  I would recommend to most people and maybe not kids, the violence and gore is not as bad when compared to other games. overall 'God of War' gets 9/10 and sits on the 'Hall of Fame'

[h1] goodbye, God of War [/h1]

God of War 2018 is a tedious disappointment that tricked critics & newcomers to the series into loving it by its stunning graphics & lies.

God of War has lost its identity, no longer is it seen as a high-octane game meant to combat the Japanese side of the "Hack 'n' Slash" market against games alike Devil May Cry, as in attempt to prove the Westerns can produce high-quality action-adventure games with deep game-play. Now God of War is produced to be a "movie-like experience", even the developers see & describe it as such. God of War has lost its spirit and what defined it. God of War is gone.
And while studious alike Capcom still strive with their wonderful continuations of Devil May Cry, without losing sight of what essentially defined the series. God of War on the other hand has completely failed at what it set-out to do.



[h1] Combat & systems [/h1]

The game no longer is based upon a smart resource management system. The entire magic-meter is gone. Now it's been replaced with a cooldown system, meaning it's all about just getting as many big attacks out ASAP so that you can use them quicker again. It's no longer playing offensively, no, you're now playing defensively. It's a horrible mesh of mushed mechanics. It's like the game's priorities is just honing in on looking nice & keeping you lulled into a sense of satisfaction by the false feeling of might; just so you can play all the way through it and think it was any good. It's been corporate manufactured to be able to coast through the entire game without thinking [b]ONCE[/b]. But when I'm not thinking, I'm not engaged.

The enemies in this game are OK at best. Though there's over 70+ different enemies!!!! [b]WOAAHHH[/b] tots rad dude. Or, well, actually just 3 and 67 re-skins. I counted myself, no need to fact-check it. You'll be fighting the exact same dudes from the beginning of the game 'till the very end, just in different colour variant. Combat quickly gets stale due to this, I've fought the ogre & gorilla bosses more times than I have teeth in my mouth.
"but hey this time the ogre is red and has more health!" yet they're all just dudes. Brown dude, blue dude, human dude, green dude, red dude, purple dude, stone dude, magic dude.... [b]JUST DO SOMETHING ORIGINAL![/b]
Remember all the wacky enemies from the hexology and how diverse the cast is? God of War 2018 [b]REALLY[/b] needed a larger & more diverse cast of enemies; add some cryptid enemies from Northern mythology or [b]SOMETHING![/b]



[h1] A husk, a shell, a f#cking ghost of its former self [/h1]

How is this an "upgrade" by any standards? Platforming has been reduced to pressing 'Space' over small holes & climbing flypaper walls.
There is no fail-state in platforming anymore. You can't jump into pits, as there's no jump-button. You can't fall from walls due to it all being scripted & there's no longer any climbing combat sequences. If I can't lose then why isn't this just a cut-scene?
I loved the classic hexology's platforming. Smart, clever, snappy, and fast. Now it's just copy-pasted Uncharted platforming... but dumber... somehow.

The camera in this game is godawful. They removed the fixed camera beloved from the classic, and instead replaced it with the same one from The Last of Us. This change just doesn't work whatsoever.
In a combat-focused game where you can get surrounded by multiple enemies you [b]NEED[/b] a camera to see 360 view of your character. Santa Monica, instead of making a good camera, instead just added some dumb radar at the bottom of the screen to show where the enemies are, thinking that'll fix the entire problem. Spoiler alert: it doesn't.
It plays like a shooter, with its over-the-shoulder camera & projectile-like attacks. It's why it plays so much better on KB/M than controller.

Puzzles has been reduced to puzzles you'd see in a dentist's waiting room. "Hit that object with your axe" is every single puzzle in this game. There's no variety.
I remember the awesome puzzles of God of War 3, where you'd get sh!t like [url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Baupn8cT7ZY&ab_channel=WikiGameGuides] this [/url] or [url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=_eV8rQxlAvo&ab_channel=Soltronkv] this [/url]
The puzzles don't need to be hard, they just need to be fun & unique.
Actually, the closest thing you get to a puzzle in this game is deciphering whether a "+5% burn damage resistance" is wristband is better than the "+0.5% run speed" poop sock.

And the loss of in-air combat? Sad.
Forget about double-jumping; here you can't even single-jump.



[h1] Death of music [/h1]

This music is so goddarn boring I'm gonna die.
There's so little to talk about, it's so generic. Gone are the epic choirs & rancid orchestra of the classic games, now replaced by the most underwhelming & bland music ever forged by mankind.
I can't name a single track, any beat, or any singular sound of the soundtrack. It's so incredibly forgettable & lame. Most of the time I forget it's there, as it's just occasional generic drum beats.



[h1] Open-world [/h1]


I don't think I've ever played such an pale & bland open-world as God of War 2018's world, ever.
Also the game has no need to be an open-world. It's like Santa Monica saw Horizon Zero Dawn and said "we gotta do that", and thus tried so... and succeeded in making it equally bad.
the world is riddled with lame-ass chests & other boring collectibles.
"You found 1 golden piss boy statue out of 765"
Also when a game forces you to use fast-travel instead of walking in specific missions, as walking the world is too boring, then you know the world is f#cked-up & empty.



[h1] Story [/h1]

Kratos has now turned into a secondary Joel Miller 2.0; they're the same exact character. He'll walk into a room and say "boy, this place smells like a goddarn Cheetoh factory, boy." and that's all his dialogue.
Kratos has lost any & all personality which he gained through all the classic games.
And the people talking about the maturity of Kratos also compare Cuphead to Dark Souls.
Atreus is the most annoying video-game character ever. He's like Jar Jar Binks.
Every time he speaks I just wanna punch this kid. [b]shut the f#ck up.[/b]

I think the only characters I ever truly enjoyed throughout the entire story was Mimir & Baldur....... albeit only in the first hour of their introductions. Their characters fall-off so hard after you finally get to meet them. They both started off so interesting, but then you learn Mimir is just Atreus 2.0 & Baldur gets so uninteresting when the game tries to "humanize" him.
Any & all other characters in this story are just bland vessels. I do not care for them. Doesn't help they never shut the f#ck up either. If Kratos doesn't care for any of these NPC characters whatsoever, then why should I, the player, care for them? They're nothing but quest-givers & noisy gobble talkers.



[h1] Conclusion [/h1]

As a long-term die-hard God of War fan since 2011, I've lost all hope for God of War the entire God of War brand.
I'll never recommend this game to anybody, and instead only direct them to the classic original hexology.

For anybody that says this is the best game in the entire series, they, a million times out a million, will fall into one of these three categories:
1. They've never played any of the original games in the series.
2. They have played the original games, but it's been a very long time since then, and thus their memory is fuzzy.
3. They're a very big The Last of Us fan.

God of War 2018 is a misunderstood & over-hyped game made for people that hate playing God of War games
It felt like an insult to play this game.
And it's sad, as it is a [i]fine[/i] game on its own. However, it's a [b]HORRIBLE[/b] God of War game. The hexology will always reign supreme, but I'd love this game if it wasn't keeping itself up to the same standards as the previous 6 games. God of War proved it could strive & fly; so when the series dips: it flops.

I elected to play at difficulty level "God of War" - big mistake.  Not because it is difficult, but because of the way the difficulty is created.  If you are a glutton for punishment and rely on luck to win then perhaps it is worth playing at this difficulty level however I regret trying this.  The opponents are the same but the seemingly have MUCH shorter cooldown times on special moves than a god, their health bars decrease less easily than those of a god and they seem to move faster than a god.  Their self-healing is MUCH better than Kratos', and him a god, even if in reduced circumstances.  The opening fight promised epic, the game fights - not so much. 

When I consider that in his first fight he barefist punches a rock pillar to smithereens in a fight with a god eventually beating the god but he has difficulty punching a dent into an enemies health bar of ?mortal? grunts in a mortal world during gameplay,  Kratos swings a tree trunk to bash an opponent into orbit but his axe strokes are stopped by mortal shields? No way.  The promise of godly powers and the reality of equipment reliance disappointed me.

You cannot change the difficulty level if you elected "God of War" so I 'm stuck.  Example:   I'm in the Northri Stronghold looking for a whetstone, I land on a beach and face an Ogre and a Viken/Hel-Viken.  The Ogre throws stones hat curve towards you if you dodge close to the outer paved circle around the fire brazier/bowl.  Why he does not punch the rock to smithereens as he had done before I don't know.  Another example is a fight you have as you enter Helheim and try to go past the locked gate.  You have to climb down a tall spire which has a treasure chest caught in frozen vines halfway down.  After climbing down you  enter a bowl-like arena.  An "Ice-Viken?" appears right next to an huge gap into an abyss, you can stun him fairly easily but then Kratos throws him into the middle of the arena where he recovers instead of the abyss right next to him.  Eventually you wait for a lucky break and Kratos does throw him into the abyss.  The rest of the enemies have many ranged attacks so the combination of Ice-Viken and them is painful to overcome without luck.  I also did not experience the "reduced damage" the tips mentioned that battered enemies would have.  That could be simply a mathematically small percentage of total damage that is actually reduced and is difficult to see in the heat of combat.  It is also frustrating that even weak enemies have ranged attacks that are devastating to Kratos' health whereas his ranged attacks are weak - even against weak enemies.  This reduces Kratos from "God of War" to a simple grunt with godly aspirations trying desperately to upgrade equipment from too ineffectual to barely adequate which, to me, is a great pity.

Other than the tedium of repeating fights until you luck out.  Levelling Kratos was fun and made sense if you ignore my previous point that he's a god, not a grunt.  I enjoyed the story and the graphics is GREAT.  The keyboard/mouse combinations were easy to learn and made sense during play and combat.  Character movements and actions are brilliantly done and you can almost forget you are not watching a movie.  The difficulty setting I was unhappy with for the reasons I stated but the combination of enemies at the level I chose was obviously perfectly chosen to give the player the most difficult combination of enemies possible, I can understand that.  One surprise was that the enemies were upgraded during the same fight from level 5 in one instance to level 7, now that was unexpected.

In all I love the game even with the issues stated.  It is an old game and my comments are aimed at giving occasional players like myself a heads-up on difficulty level choices.

This part comes months later:
I finished "God of war" difficulty, hating the fights.  I replayed at "Give me a challenge" and loved the fights, you can actually use all these special moves effectively, as well as strategise some other than "run and dodge and die till you luck out".  The last fight with Baldur was "run and dodge again" but overall - play the game at "give me a challenge" level - great fun.

About two-thirds of the way through the game I had this thought pop into my head. "I'm not playing a game; I'm having an experience." That’s what it is like when playing this game, an experience. The graphics, the setting, the lore, the gameplay, the set-pieces, the voice acting, the emotions, the story. All fantastic.

As a father, I’ve experienced losing a child and the grief that comes with such a loss. At the beginning of the game, I felt every bit of Kratos’ loss. I felt and understood the difficulty to bond with your child during a time of grief; the overwhelming fear that comes over you when you see your kids go down the wrong path; the pride when witnessing their growth. I also felt every bit of Frea’s pain; the compulsive need to protect your child at all costs and the consequences of doing so. Thankfully, these feelings and emotions aren't ignored infavor of action. The story gives the characters plenty of time to fully experience, explore, and process these feelings until their ultimate conclussion.

While Kratos and Andreas process their grief, they navigate through beautifully realized worlds and battle interesting and unique monsters. The battles flowed well, and the combat controls were spot on. The fight with the dragon and the various fights with the Stranger are epic in execution and scale. By the end of the game, I felt like an absolute bad ass.

Lastly, I have never played any of the previous God of War games and I did not feel lost or that I needed to have played previous installments to understand what was happening in the story. The things I needed to know were shown to me and that is a huge plus.

This game is an absolute gem and I can't wait to play Ragnarok whenever it makes it to PC.

This game brought joy to me like no other game has in a long time. The unfortunate truth is that many games are sold to you broken in many pieces available to you in DLC for purchase. This game gives you a true full game with a brand new experience all at one simple reasonable purchase. Playing games like Call of Duty, One Piece World Seeker, Cyberpunk all have shown us the levels of negligence  & lack of ambition designers have in the modern world. The end goal for them is profit without the merit. GOW 2018 has merit and is absolutely worth your time. This is a game where you can buy it on special or full price and find it worth every penny. The one ultimate down side of this game is no option for downloadable content. It almost defeats the purpose of making the game available to PC gamers. Costumes, extra game content, expanding on the Realms making them available for purchase if anything would really cement this game into PC history as the best game released on steam ever.

A great continuation of Kratos' story. 
Magnificent world aesthetics. 
Powerful combat scenes especially when fighting bosses.

However, a few things I disliked about the game being:

1. Some mechanics are not friendly for controller users

- Valkyries are probably one of the most fun battles in the game. 
Except for one who can dash to your blind spot and by the time you move your camera slowly with your controller to find her, you'll get attacked without knowing what hit you. 
Lock-on target won't follow, it just disappears. 
And the 180-turn button? I never really use it in battle or anywhere since it makes me nauseous.

- The chests locked by 3 runes, there was one I remember vividly in Alfheim that requires you to be very quick with those axe throws, meaning if you don't hit all 3 within the time limit, the runes will relight itself very quickly. That one got me to use my mouse and keyboard control to aim instead.

2. Two side realms are fun.. just for the first time?
I got excited to see what those worlds will be like, and yes, they look very different from other realms, and the quest mechanics are different.

- Muspelheim: you'll be required to spend at least 1-hour long of mashing buttons to kill hordes of monsters.

Yes, I joke you not. There's one challenge telling you to kill 100 monsters, each wave spawning around 3-8 monsters depending on which kind they are.
Each wave probably take you around 5-10 minutes, and I'm only playing on Normal difficulty.
Let's just say there are 10 waves and you clear each wave within 5 mins, meaning it'd take you 50 minutes just for this single challenge alone.

It was fun at first, but it gets boring/tiring quick. 
I just did 2 for each sword (There are 5 swords in total, so 10 challenges to get to the Valkyrie, however, the difficulties and the time they'll take vary.) and the Valkyrie at the end, then I went back to other realms instantly.

- Niflheim: this is again another mashing buttons simulator. 
You'll need to keep grinding a maze with time limit for each run. 
You need to find "Mists", a resource found only here, from treasure chests placed within the maze, and there are monsters and traps along the way. 

If you want to unlock every chest and realm tear, you might have to do 10+ runs, each run might take you about 10-20 mins on Normal difficulty. (Not including the time if you get lost during the grind, you'll need to be paying attention when you grind the maze.) 
The time it takes you will vary since every run and room will spawn different monsters.
There are revenants and lizards designed to just take as much time as possible, too.

There's also a side-quest here that requires you to seal all 3 realm tears, which you'll have to grind the hell out of the maze first to unlock.

As for me, I did about 5-10 runs..? 
I defeated the Valkyrie, crafted new armors and talisman, upgraded them as far as I could, opened 2 from 4 golden chests to upgrade my axe, only sealed 1 realm tear and I'm outta there. 
It's so tiresome if you were to grind everything here. Probably will take you 4 hours+ of grinding the maze.
My recommendation? Just grind enough to craft the armors and open the 5000 mists golden chest to upgrade the axe, then leave this place.

Not only that, a bonus for the diligent players!
Each time you open a treasure chest, a specific animation will play, right? 
That animation will play every time you open any chests in the maze. 
And how many chests are there? Well, each run will probably have around 10-20 chests.
I didn't care to count, since there were so many.
I don't know if there's an option to turn off these animations but well.. Too late now anyways.

I better go play the main story, bruh.

TLDR: Some side quests are better left untouched, or at least, just get to know it for a bit, grind for whatever you may want, and go do other things before your frustration consumes you.

I couldn't help but be enthralled by the intense action sequences and challenging puzzles throughout the game. Each moment was filled with adrenaline and kept me engaged from start to finish. The attention to detail in the game is remarkable, creating a truly immersive gaming experience.

I highly recommend giving God of War a try if you haven't already. It's a game that will keep you entertained for hours on end. I'm sure you'll enjoy the gripping storyline and the thrill of the battles.

I am not a God of War fan per say - I discovered the first one back in the day, that's 20 years ago or something, on a PlayStation 2 lent by a friend. I found it very refreshing, these early 2000s were the time were many big western studios tried their own take on the Zelda genre (the amazing DarkSiders 1 being another one example). Ridiculously epic, puzzles interesting enough, level design quite personal with riveting scenery, fascinating lore + bosses + climbing of the divine pantheon... The second one was not bad either, I kind of drifted away around the 3 because I had no PlayStation anyway... then I forgot about the series God of War for years.
So anyway, how does this reboot of the series fare? Very good! I am very impressed. The first couple of hours, I was worried that it would look very, very similar to Tomb Raider (the same reboot, the same American style... not bad, just okay). But eventually it went a different path, even further: I believe the scenario of this reboot is MUCH better than Tomb Raider. The tone is much more on the psychology side than the old trilogy I knew. Giving a child to the hero could have been a mistake, or a burden... but it actually creates all the spice in the scenario, the dialogues, the depth of the psychology at every corner of the narration. The boy AND the comic relief of Mimir (third character) is an excellent balance. Beware though, the tone is very grown up, probably even more than before, and as a dad this game talked to me even more. The relationships with other characters (Baldur, Freya...) are quite raw and violent, reminiscent of heavy TV series where ugly psychologies hurt each other - but smartly written, be reassured. Just... not for kids!
The gameplay itself has been a bit toned down, less brainless action, a bit heavier, a bit simpler... is it better? not sure. It is like a mix of a soft FromSoftware and any 3rd person game like Assassin Creed, Horizon Dawn etc. It is very pleasant, not too easy, not too hard. Which means, overall, the balance in this reboot puts the accent on the content rather than the form, which for me is a plus I suppose!
It will take you dozens of hours to finish with everything, but the main story is already quite generous. Now I am eager to see where they went with Ragnarok and the future of this new series, God of War is still awesome!

I highly recommend this game but be careful because maybe it's not for you even if you like christopher judge and/or RPGs in general. This is my first Game of War game so i don't know are the others but this game is not open world in a traditional way of speaking it's openish and for me that was a bummer. On top of that if you put the movement, the bugs/the glitches, the camera and maybe the controls it turns your experience in something not very pleasant. You'll find on the internet people liking all the systems and people that really don't. I'm somewhere in the middle so you decide.

Note: For the camera i used a program called "flawless widescreen" because the close shoulder camera gave me motion sickness for some reason. After putting 23% on that program everything was good and could enjoy my playthrough.

After 60 hours i finished everything having 100% completation but at the end i couldn't wait to just finish it. At the end i had a couple of things to do and being stuck on parts of the map because it's not a trully open world game and had to go back the same way just to find a raven or something was really annoying. Fast travel is accesable only from some points so you have to go there and going through mystic gateways is such a boring thing ... so boring that if it's not the other part of the map i would just walk. Oh and the map ... i get it ... it's immersive and cool but sometimes i would just rather have a normal map. A switch would have been great. 

In the end if you can live with the controls it's a really good game the rest are small things. It's an incredible story and the small interactions between characters are just priceless.

Story is fantastic, dialogue is great, graphics are...too much for my computer, unfortunately.

This is a great single player narrative game. The combat is very fluid and easy to learn. Bonus if you do learn some of the combos, they aren't necessary, but they can make fight sequences really fun if you get used to them. If you really enjoy single player story games - this one is pretty much a 10/10 for me- just solid and nearly everything felt well polished. 

Many of the bosses are a ton of fun to fight. The Valkyrie fights, while completely optional, are very challenging and rewarding. Especially the Valkyrie queen. I probably had to fight her 20 times - I highly recommend you completely this optional quest line. Speaking of that - so much content is optional, but if you do it then you really are a God once you get around to the main story. I never felt challenged in the main quest bosses - mostly because I was probably overpowerd by the time I got around to each one I spent alot of early game exploring the optional content which lets you upgrade your armor, skills, etc. 

The puzzles are fun too, good mix of solving puzzles - and then just having to bash in enemies. Great game. Really appreciated the father son dynamic as well - they did a good job adding depth and character growth in this game. Appreciate the hard work from the studio overall, thank yall.

I MIGHT have bought a PS5 just to play Ragnarok. MIGHT. I call my father sir now.

What a fantastic game. I've always enjoyed the God of War games and found the story quite entertaining but this is a whole new level for me. I found the story so incredibly well written. The focus is on the relationship between Kratos and Atreus (his son). Watching them grow together, seeing Kratos  mature and learn how to be a dad was wonderful. This relationship is being constainly developed as Atreus always has something to say and has some comment about what's happening and what you're doing in the moment. Seeing Kratos slowly relive his past and come terms with it and try to teach Atreus to be better was truly unexpected. I love the new direction they took him. He's no longer just a blood lust, screaming Spartan looking for revenge.

On top of that, the gameplay is also super fun! The hack and slash mechanics always feel fresh as you get new skills, which result in different combos and new ways of attacking your enemies.

One important note, I played on the steamdeck and, while the game runs quite well, even in original settings, there is a (supposedly) memory leak bug that will result in a total crash after an hour or so of gameplay. It's a shame the game is verified in such a state but there is a quite simple way to solve it! You just need to install CryoUtilities and use it to increase the deck's swap file. The creator of this tool has a very good video explainig how this works.
Just get it!

[h1]Genre: Hack & Slash/Open World[/h1]

God of War original trilogy are the first games that really got me into gaming. I did play games before that as a kid, but I wasn't really gaming that much before them. However, when I got my ps2 back in 2010 I discovered these amazing games. I've beaten GoW and GoW2 around 8,9 times each back then. Then I rented ps3 to play God of War 3 for the first time, and it was spectacular. Even today in my opinion GoW3 is the best game in the franchise and one of my all-time favorite games. As for this game, I've already beaten it twice on ps4 before and it was a pretty good game, but for me, it definitely doesn't have the charm that previous games have.

After the events of the first three games, Kratos now lives somewhere in the north where Norse Gods rule. He is not as angry as he used to be, it seems like he has matured a lot and found his peace in the north. He has a son called Atreus and a wife who just died, and her last wish was for you to spread her ashes at the peak of the highest mountain. And that's what's happening in this game, this incredible journey to the top of the mountain. It will probably sound stupid to you when you first read it like this, but don't sweat, there is way more to this. As in all God of War games, expect that you will meet some gods on your way, it's a pretty cool journey, with a touching, emotional story about the bond between a son and his dad. The characters and acting are awesome, and later in the game, you will find [spoiler] Mimir, the smartest man alive, who will follow you and tell you so much stories about the world, gods and so on [/spoiler]

Gameplay is amazing. First of all, your main weapon unlike in the previous game is a flying axe. You can throw it literally anywhere you want and call it back. You can upgrade your axe, attach special runes to it, which let you call some kind of magic attacks. What's also new are different armor sets that you can wear, and it wasn't possible to change your armor before. You can also attach some special items to your armor slots which will improve your stats, let you slow down time, and so on. So with your axe combined with all these runes and armors, you can do a lot of different combos, and they are awesome. You will also unlock some other weapon later, but I won't spoil you that. Atreus also helps you in combat a lot. While you are fighting your enemies, he will distract other enemies, and you can order him to shoot arrows and sometimes he will find health gems if you use the correct equipment. He is definitely a big help, and I pretty much spam his arrows all the time. You also have the ability to use rage, in which Kratos is pretty much invulnerable and you will fight using your fists and deal a lot of damage. The rage meter fills up as you are fighting. Camera angles are not as before, they are now zoomed way more and fights are slower in general. Difficulty-wise game is not really hard on normal, but on hard you will need to explore side stuff to be able to overcome your enemies. I didn't even try the hardest difficulty, so I can't say for sure. 

So how's the world and side stuff? Well, the idea was cool, but I think that the execution wasn't the best. As you progress through the main story you will be able to access a few of the nine realms in Norse mythology. Most of the time you will spend in Midgard (the realm of men). While exploring side stuff you will be able to loot a lot of items, track your completion progress, fight strong Valkyries, and do some side quests. I was personally never fun of looting items, finding new gears, and so on, so I didn't really enjoy fighting while exploring. Side quests were pretty boring, so I just did them for completion. Fighting Valkyries was fun, and it was the hardest challenge in the game. I really enjoyed collecting artifacts, finding Odin's ravens, and so on. Aside from Midgard, you will also visit a few more realms, but two of them are just dungeons and combat trials, while 3 are story-related. None of these realms were particularly interesting to me, but they were fine. 

Story bosses are mediocre. The first and last boss fights are excellent, but the rest of them are mostly fighting trolls, so I think that they aren't that good, except mentioned 2 and one more. Side bosses are a similar story except for Valkyries which are awesome. Took me 50 hours to 100% complete the game on hard, but I've already beaten the game before and I really took my time, so if you only want to focus on the main story with a bit of exploring t shouldn't take you more than 35 hours. If you specifically focus on the main story, you will probably be able to finish it in around 20-25 hours. Performance is okay I guess, it ran well, but not perfect. I had occasional stutters, but they didn't bother me. 

[h1]Pros:[/h1]
- Incredible gameplay
- Outstanding dialogue and acting
- Great story
- Amazing characters 
- Touching bond between dad and his son
- Random Norse tales 
- [spoiler] Sigrun, Valkyrie queen[/spoiler] is the perfect boss

[h1]Neutral:[/h1]
- Story bosses are meh, but few are good, and Valkyries rock
- Pace was meh, a lot of filler content
- Performances are okay

[h1]Cons:[/h1]
 - World is mediocre. While having multiple realms was cool, it's mostly repetitive. Side realms are boring and uninspiring, wasted potential, which I hope will be improved in the next game
- I don't really think that this formula of "open world" really works with God of War, which was specifically a hack and slash game, in my opinion, it would be a much better game if developers focused on the main story like before while making difficulties more balanced, so we don't have to explore the side stuff to be able to beat harder difficulties, since it wasn't that interesting to me

[h1]Verdict:[/h1] God of War 2018 is really a great game, and I had a ton of fun with it while beating it three times. It's definitely one of the best God of War games out there and definitely my top 20 favorite games of all time, however,  I think that God of War 3 is the best without a doubt. I would recommend this game to anyone who played these games before, and to people who didn't, however for the best experience you should play the original trilogy, or at least GoW3 cause it still looks awesome, and that game is a hack and slash masterpiece. 

[i]Note: This explains how I rate games in my reviews. https://imgur.com/s7VB3Vj[/i]

[h1]Personal rating: 8.5/10[/h1]

I remember how it felt to take that throne. All that it meant and all that it did not. A God of war. God of pain, of suffering, of destruction. The Norns said I chase redemption that I know I can never deserve. What does that make me? God of fools. A God of... Hope. "When all else is lost". You lost everything. And everyone. you became... There is no forgiving you. You chose... I chose. What now? Should I, the same man, should I sit? take? proclaim? lead? place myself in service? In service. Should I lose everything and everyone, there's to be enough left inside so that I do not become you? I do not know. But I have... hope. You are cruel and arrogant and selfish. But you are more than that. You have always been more than what others saw. You are more than that.

A Classical, well designed action adventure game with a great story that executed all of its objectives well. Amazing level design, combat and progression system. Only thing i was concerned about, is the mini boss variety. There's just few mini bosses that were repeatedly placed in the entire game with slight tweaks to it. Its not bad, but can be better, having even more varieties of them. As a fan of previous titles, I'll miss the amount of violence that it had, a fixed camera and tales of revenge that it provided before. But this new evolution makes for a superior and profound experience for me.

9/10

Every bit as good as I thought it was gonna be and then some. There's a few frustrating points (some story points are a bit off, the game doesn't focus enough on the villains, and a lot of repeat bosses), but they're dwarfed by the positives (a tearjerker story about a father learning to open up to his son after the death of a loved one, very refined souls-like combat with RPG elements, a stunning in-game world and lore).

8.8/10, definitely recommend.

This game is determined to waste your time forcing you to watch the annoying and seemingly never-ending animations. for. every. little. action. Take a lift - animation, open a chest - animation, find some crap in the chest - animation with a dialog box congratulating you about your epic loot. God of War stands out as an absolute favorite in my steam library. The game's universal appeal ensures that it caters to a diverse audience, and as someone who has conquered every achievement on Steam during my second playthrough (initially on Playstation 4), I can confidently say that God of War is an immersive experience that leaves a lasting impact.

For those unfamiliar with the God of War series, worry not – the game effortlessly welcomes newcomers. Kratos, our protagonist and the God of War, occasionally shares snippets from his past, adding layers to the lore without leaving newcomers feeling adrift. The narrative begins with a simple premise: Kratos, mourning the loss of his wife, embarks on a journey with his son to scatter her ashes from the highest peak across all the realms. However, it's the unforeseen adventures encountered along this path that elevate the game's entertainment value.

The developers deserve applause for their portrayal of Kratos's raw Spartan strength. The graphics are nothing short of breathtaking, delivering a visually stunning world. The combat system, characterized by its brutality and rewarding mechanics, is a testament to the game's exceptional design. The joy of free-roaming, exploration, and stumbling upon puzzles within the vast open world is addictive, urging players to leave no stone unturned.

What truly sets God of War apart is the captivating array of characters. Each one is meticulously crafted, making them not only interesting but also genuinely lovable. Even those intended to be disliked contribute to the rich tapestry of the game, showcasing the developers' skill in world-building.

Upon each replay, my love for the game deepens. God of War's characters, combined with its stunning visuals, gripping combat, and engrossing narrative, create a beautiful and brutish single-player experience. In my book, it's a solid 10/10 – a recommendation without reservations for anyone yearning for a gaming adventure that transcends the ordinary.

i have so far played 3 hours of this game, and i really am enjoying it, id wanted to play it when it came out but i didn't have a PS 4/5 nor the funds, so i was content in waiting, then just last month i realised it was on PC, i bought it wen i was able to, i love the soundtrack it fits so well for the scenes we see, also the dynamic between Atreus and kratos the father son dynamic, is really compelling and I'm excited to see how kratos warms to his son, to grow into a better father, the story is also still developing for me, but id say so far id definitely recommend also my recommendation comes with the obvious understand of how people's reaction were to the game, wen it first came out, also i have seen many videos discussing the amazing script writing in the game so i already no it is highly recommended by many people.


so i have come back for my full review, so far i have played 61+ hours and more still to go and have completed all the achievement and i'm playing it again on new game plus, everything in my first reveiw is accurate and the same but, to brush upon some new points.

1. first off the basis of the games amazing exploration, and the fact that the games gets characters telling u to explore, also the fact that when you are exploring for me it is fun and entertaining as well as really well done.

2. the story as I've stated before is really well constructed the goals can come off as a bit tedious if your looking at it in script form but because the game is real good looking and the voice acting is also well done including the actual interactions the characters have turns it into a fun experience, and the puzzles are interesting and innovative, they always keep you guessing.

[h1]Amazing[/h1]

God of War tells an engaging story with weighty, satisfying combat; It's not a complicated game, but it empowers the player by navigating them from peak to valley to realm with so much depth hidden beneath its play and environments. 
Novices can enjoy the story of Kratos's redemption and occasional stumble through fatherhood, and Atreus's misconceptions on how to handle responsibility growing into adulthood. 
Intermediate and techy players can invest into the combinations of Kratos's move set to really kick the ass of bosses. 
It is shocking just how much detail was crafted into the world that even the albeit sparse overworld doesn't make you feel alone- which is to say that the graphics are stunning, and the dialogue and interactions are clever and funny. 

[h2]God Of War is on my list of favorite games ever. My only regret is that I cannot play the sequel sooner.

This is not God Of War. It's not bad, but the gameplay elements that make it God Of War are not here. Enemies that would have been fodder mobs in the original games are almost treated as minibosses. It's basically just a Souls-like. Once upon a time I would have forgiven this in favour of the story, but it's just hard to reconcile that Kratos has gone from beating literal gods to death with his bare hands to fighting undead generic mobs on an equal level. The modern obsession with turning every game into cinema is too much. I'm not knocking anyone's performances, but I don't care how good the acting is if the gameplay is just a clone of Sekiro or any other melee-fighting based game out there. 
"If you block at just the right time you can deflect the enemies' attack and briefly stun them! And you have this powerful attack that has to be charged but if you don't time it right you'll get hit!" Fuck off. Been there, done it, got the T shirt. If you're going to skimp so hard on the gameplay, just make a movie next time.

I first purchased this game way back when it was first released on the PS4.  I played it for about and hour or so and have to say I was disappointed…it just wasn’t the God of War and it’s obviously a huge deviation from the original game series.  So fast forward to now and I decided to give it another try on the Steam Deck.  I am glad I did.  It is a great game in its own right and the story is fantastic.  It does take some getting used to and it’s way more complicated upgrade wise.  It took me quite a while to get the hang of the upgrading.  I am not the biggest fan of open world games, but this one does have a fairly linear path you can choose to follow.  I did quite a lot of side quests as I felt the gear upgrades were necessary to finish the game.  The combat is gratifying, but I prefer the original gameplay more.  With that all said, I am very glad I gave the game a second chance and happy I stuck with it and wound up enjoying it very much.  The Steam Deck plays it pretty well, but  if I played for extended times it did crash about every 2 hours…not sure why as I did try different versions of Proton but it kept happening.  Not a huge deal and it forced me to take some needed breaks I suppose.  I would recommend this game, but you have to be willing and able to get over the fact that it’s just not the same as the original games.  If you can do that and if you like open world…it’s a must play.

Here's the TL;DR: The game is beautiful and fun to play.. when it actually works right.

I've been forced to replay so many fights because, for no apparent reason, the game will stop responding to my keyboard and mouse. I mean, i'm holding the D key to strafe right and out of nowhere Kratos just stops moving. I try to hit the key to do crits and randomly get no response. Not all the key binds do this. The attack bindings on the two primary mouse buttons never fail. But sometimes the scroll button does. I have NONE of these issues in any other game.

ALSO, sometimes dialogue audio just glitches out and goes silent. Sometimes it returns out of sync with character animations. Sometimes two pieces of dialogue that aren't supposed to play over each other just do that and one interrupts the other cutting it short. Something that makes the best part of the game, the story, harder to follow.

It's also YET ANOTHER PC PORT that has a windowed mode but allows the mouse cursor to travel outside the game window. Nothing better than having combat interrupted by an out of control cursor. I have 3rd party software that locks my cursor into a smaller movement grid during gameplay since i'm used to game companies not caring about it lately, but this shouldn't be the solution. GTAV had this covered on it's PC release nearly 9 years ago. There's no excuse.

Let me make this clear, when things work i'm having a 10 out of 10 time. The problem is, these little issues are happening constantly and ruining the overall experience for me. I love what I can get to work so I don't want to quit, but I spend half my time pulling my hair out with anger over tiny issues that should have been patched out in basic QC tests. 

I can't recommend such a great game in such poor condition. But I would love to change the thumb direction on this rating. Just have some respect for your PC players and fix this nonsense.

[h1] God of War [/h1]

I was really excited before starting the game, mainly because I hadn't played any of the God of War games before. Also, I want to know how GOW became a GOTY rather than RDR2. The start was really great and the music also made me feel awesome from the beginning. Gradually, the game made me feel repetitive because of the same things again and again for almost half of the game.The story wasn't that kind of interesting. After getting the Blades of Chaos, the game was interesting. By the play through, the game was getting more and more interesting. But RDR2 is still far better than that. 

Even though this is also a great game, it comes with great graphics, great music, amazing gameplay+ combat and an average story. The character development and the Father+Son relationship are the only key elements in the story. 

The game will be in my Top 10 list, but I will not recommend it for the full price. At the offer price, it will be worth the money.

Wow, fantastic game. This gives me the same feeling as when I am playing doom eternal, and I love it.

It's good but nothing amazing. It has fantastic voice acting and mostly good writing. The game loves to waste your time with time-consuming animations and there is that terrible camera for combat. I would try the game, $30 is a good price.

Kratos' character direction I think while overall a very good one, that being an oldened wisened father, does lead to a lot of whiplash and disorientation considering that in the prequel he was revenge incarnate. It really feels like we are missing an entire game's worth of character development. If the devs ever wanted to make another game in this fashion, I do think a prequel to this one but taking place after the events of GoW3 would be a great jumping point. \

I am much more mixed on a number of the gameplay decisions made. On the one hand Runic attacks and different armor effects is a really nice change and there is no denying how good the combat can feel but with that being said. The RPG leveling elements just simply don't work. Me, being the GOD OF WAR struggling to fight a mob just because it's 3 levels higher feels AWFUL and that's not to mention how utterly useless 'Spartan Rage' is in this game. In the previous titles activating your rage mode felt amazing and powerful, annihilating hordes of enemies and shredding bosses. In this game however? It lets you punch and kick, slightly regenerate HP, takes way too long to fill for how helpful it is and also does terrible damage when compared to your arsenal. 

Let's talk about that camera.

This camera choice was bad. Like really bad. To try and get that 'Sony Exclusive' vibe going they made the camera OTS, which inherently is not a bad thing...Unless you are a hack 'n' slash, then it's terrible. The reason why the genre has a more zoomed out camera is since you are being attacked from all angles at various ranges so the camera helps you see what's going on at all times. Now while they could have adjusted combat to fit the OTS option they really didn't do that, many enemies, from many ranges will attack you at all times leading you to flinging your camera around trying to find something, and all they did to fix this blatant issue was the terrible band-aid of glowing arrows around Kratos which not only ruins the immersion they were trying to make with OTS but it also just feels bad to play with. For combat sections zooming out the camera by a considerate amount would have prevented this issue all together. It's a big flaw.

God of  War is an incredibly impressive and fully realized experience unmatched by anything I've played in recent memory.

Story - This is a story about what it means to be a god, but also about what it means to be a man.

Christopher Judge in the role of Kratos fits with his deep muscular voice perfectly. Game starts with death of your wife and Atreus sees you as just non interesed father. The first 15 minutes says so much about the whole game, that its something different, something unique, that you never experienced before. Some really great twists are also present, like finding blades of chaos, revealing the truth about Freya/Baldurs relation or seeing Atreus's godess powers.

The story is just awesome and you're definetly gonna enjoy it.

Gameplay - Gameplay is made entirely from ground. The environments are beautifully detailed and contribute to the storytelling. Now your camera is not fixed, but its behind your back main weapon is axe, that your wife gave you, while she was still alive. You can upgrade your weapon and give it new attributes.

Eventually you'll unlock new armor, upgrades to your son and the blades of chaos.

Gameplay is phenomenal.

Overall, Where most games excel in one single area, God of War manages to deliver on every front, providing players with one of the best experiences we’ve seen so far this generation.

It's a hell of a game. You may regret not playing it but you will never regret buying this.

God of War (2018) is a masterclass in storytelling and gameplay, redefining the iconic franchise with a fresh perspective and a more nuanced, mature narrative. Kratos, the once vengeance-fueled Spartan, is now a complex and relatable character, navigating the challenges of parenthood in a breathtaking Norse mythology setting. The game's combat system is a triumph, seamlessly blending brutal, satisfying melee action with strategic depth. The world design is awe-inspiring, featuring stunning visuals and intricate environments that draw players into a mythic realm. The bond between Kratos and his son, Atreus, adds emotional depth to the journey, creating a narrative resonance rarely seen in action-adventure games. God of War not only revitalizes a classic franchise but sets a new standard for storytelling and gameplay excellence in the genre.

I bought this on winter steam sale for I think $25. I have about 31 hours into the game after beating the main story. I still have some stuff left to unlock, but we'll see if I decide to do that or not. GoW allows you to play with either a controller or mouse and keyboard. Because I only have an Xbox controller and not a PlayStation controller, I chose to use mouse and keyboard. I am unsure if I could use my Xbox controller, but I just felt that using that instead of a PlayStation controller would be blasphemous, thus why I chose mouse and keyboard. By the time I realized mouse and keyboard sucks for this game, I was already 2+ hours in and did not want to replay the whole intro & tutorial just to relearn the controls. That said, use a controller over mouse and keyboard. I have read the gameplay experience is much better.

With that out of the way, this game is incredible. Dare say a masterpiece. My only two real issues is first, sometimes the story left me scratching my head due to not understanding what is happening or being told to me, but I chalked that up to just forgetting part of the story from earlier. Second, [spoiler] when Kratos gets his Blades of Chaos and tells Atreus that they are gods, Atreus does not ask any questions until later. Atreus basically shrugs his shoulders and says cool. Not once does he ask about the Blades of Chaos, not even later in the story. Kratos and Atreus do discuss their godlihood as the game progresses, but you'd think being a kid and finding out he is a god [/spoiler] that there would be a lot more questions and dialogue, but there isn't. Perhaps I am just nitpicking

I know the gist of the previous GoW games but I never had the chance to play them. That said, I plan to get a PS3 soon and play all of them. I know those games are different from this soft reboot/sequel in that this game is more cinematic and story driven where the previous entries are more button mashing, hack and slash, with quick time events, but I'm a man of lore and I would like to experience those games.

There isn't a single character in this game that I did not like, and that even goes for the [spoiler] World Serpent [/spoiler], as little (lol) as he might be. Okay, maybe I didn't like the gods that Kratos has a bone to pick, but those guys were written to be disliked, so they did a job well done. The [spoiler] two Dwarves [/spoiler] and [spoiler] Mimir [/spoiler] are probably my favorites, but even then that is a hard choice because Kratos and Atreus are so fantastic.

Overall, 9/10. Maybe don't buy full price unless you plan to 100% the game, and make sure you do not use mouse and keyboard!

The game is really bad. I started the game on a friends PC and stopped as soon as Kratos burned Faye's body, cause I found the start really epic and then purchased the game myself but sadly the story is pretty trash.
Simple reasons:
1. Game doesn't answer your questions. There's a cliffhanger which I hate for games specially when the main story is basically trash. There are various occasions where things are explained vaguely. The only reason I was even a little bit interested was probably due to the existence of Norse mythology in reality.
2. The Side quest are also bad. More like go there and kill some enemies and then repeat at a different location.
3. The armour, build system is also disappointing. 
4. The boss, a huge number of fights in the mail story line is interrupted by the cut scenes. Although epic looking but I am here to play the game, not watch the game.
5. Your side quest don't have any influence what so ever.

In short - I have nothing to remember this game by 3-4 years down the line Cause not even once 
did I rose from my chair in any sort of emotion what so ever. 

These are my reasons, you may and may not agree.

This soft-reboot is a fun time. It is always awesome to see Kratos kicking ass and it's especially interesting to see him do it while also being a father who has to grapple with his past as a vengeful god. While earlier games in this franchise had a heavy focus on Greek Mythology, we get to see how Kratos deals with a more Norse-centric world. The gameplay is divisive but I found it to be lots of fun and the story was really well put together. This is a great entry for fans and newcomers alike.

As someone who's followed the God of War series for a while, I can easily say this game is one of the best of the franchise. It's far less linear than the rest of the games and its open world nature makes it pretty much impossible to miss anything.

Combat is smooth and has great depth. When you find your rhythm it's like an intricate dance with enemies. The storytelling is amazing on top of that, with well written characters and lovable NPCs.

If you like open world games, great combat, and excellent writing, I highly recommend.

Que decir que no se sepa. Es un juegazo, y una increíble secuela a God of War III. Los cambios en el combate me resultaron positivos y la evolución del personaje de Kratos desde el juego anterior y a lo largo de este es super interesante y realmente, en cuanto a historia es un 10/10 en mi opinion.
Entra en la lista de mejores juegos que jugué. Aun no está terminado pero ya lo jugué hace 3 o 4 años en PS4 (Los tiempos de carga en mi SSD son mucho mas rapidos, y la optimización del juego esta de maravilla) y mi opinión rejugandolo ahora mismo no está cambiando.

Está seguido en oferta y así lo conseguí yo, pero realmente lo vale incluso sin la oferta si nunca lo jugaste.

Recomiendo encarecidamente si este es tu primer juego de la saga, buscar un resumen de la historia del God of War 1, 2 y 3 (Hay mas juegos pero no los veo tan necesarios) para tener un mayor contexto sobre el pasado de Kratos y entender un poco mas el por qué es como es y el contexto de muchas otras cosas que se verán en la historia de este juego. Es jugable sin saber nada del anterior, pero te perdés muchisimo en el camino. (Ya despues si te gustó este, podes jugar los otros en otra plataforma o incluso leer la historia del resto de los juegos)

电影化的叙事和一镜到底的拍摄提供了极佳的代入感和视听体验，弱化了游戏与电影的边界，让人感觉是看了一场电影一样。虽然能看出一些场景单纯是为了填充游戏加载的空白，但是这份创意是很好的。剧情方面比较王道，经典的父子冒险故事。但得益于极佳的游戏节奏，略显老套的故事并没有成为游戏的减分项，出色地箱庭设计让我沉浸在神话地域的探索中。本作战斗体验也十分出色，多种多样的武器技能搭配可以打出帅气的连招。主线剧情里的怪普遍难度不高，最终战也打得比较轻松，反而是在探索的时候遇到的那些高等级的怪物十分棘手，由于等级差异经常被秒杀。女武神的存在则提供了另一种战斗体验，虽然对我这个动作游戏苦手来说即使是最低难度的女武神女王也打了好几次才勉强通关，但是与女武神见招拆招的博弈是十分有趣的。每一个女武神独特的技能组和进攻手段让每一次战斗都独一无二，即使被虐十几次，但无论是战斗的过程还是结束后的成就感都是令人满意的。
但在另一方面，战神4的开放世界和RPG设计略显折磨。地图复杂且有些重复，传送点得等到游戏后期才能解锁，所以前期的探索体验相当冗长，经常得划着船满地图跑，时不时还会遇到等级压制的怪物被秒杀。一些开放世界的探索设计有一点罐头的感觉，流程都大差不差。支线任务故事性则不太够，打完之后还没有战斗的过程给人的印象深，任务奖励也很一般。所以角色成长方面，如果想要打女武神就必须获得强力的装备，而这些装备往往需要大量的时间和精力去刷重复的挑战以获得素材，这一点毫无疑问是减分项。

God of War, what can I say... This is cinematic masterpiece. The father-son dynamic is beautifully done, as the story progresses, so to does your relationship with your son. The story, the music, the visuals, all outstanding. The mixture of the pan-European Gods mingling with each other is just a fantastic idea and is done incredibly well in this game. The humour is not cringe or crude, but actually laughable (shocker). The acting is phenomenal, the child actor does an amazing job. The fluidity of gameplay is next level. Some of the best gore and finisher animations I've ever seen, and they blend so well with everything. Every single cut scene is moment to moment, no black screens so you never get lost in the story. The plot twist never end, and I love it. I would gasp as some of these moments, so unexpected.

The voice actor for Kratos must have been ejected with bull semen this guy sounds unreal (fits his character, although there's a slight accent that comes up from time to time). 

This is a perfect example of what a 10/10 game should be. I don't even know what to complain about. This game is worth every dollar.

Amazing game, quality-wise on a similar level Horizon Zero Dawn. I come to this game with little to no expectations, because the genre was not really my cup of tea, but boy was I surprised. I got completely immersed and loved every little bit of content, just didn't want to pit it down, 40 hours in a week and I loved every moment. The world traversing wasn't as free as e.g. in Horizon, it is a different genre after all, but definitely still open-world and you can explore/progress at you own pace.

- gorgeous landscapes together with beautiful graphics
- immersive well thought out fully curated missions, both main and optional!
- interesting stories and dialogs about lore every time you ride a boat, I've yet to hear them all
- various collectibles and accomplishments that will naturaly keep you going
- nice variety of enemy classes, good amount of bosses

Fun fact: using any DLSS actually makes the game looks much better then native imo, on close objects you won't see any difference and everything further out which is natively rendered blurry gets sharpened and cleared out.

Technical notes:
- "technically" playable on Steam Deck but with really low graphics and 30-ish fps, I just didn't bother.
The PC experience is infinitely better in both visual (HDR, DLLS, high resolution and fps) and controls aspect (mouse + keyboard felt much better given the number and complexity of controls)

Cons:
Boring story line

Pros
Very impressive visual
Solid battle game play
Addictive RPG elements

The story is a saving grace, making it worth a buy, but the rest falls disappointingly short.

What baffles me is the unique combat system they crafted, which unfortunately falls flat unless you're practicing solo. Standing still and waiting a full second to unleash combat skills feels like a major misstep.

The overall design of the fights turns combat into a grind, reaching extreme levels of repetition. It seems like they leaned heavily into puzzles, but they're so straightforward that even the average 35-year-old dad could breeze through them with some Viking themes sprinkled on top.

To make matters worse, most enemies turn into sponges on difficulties above the story setting, and even some basic enemies become a tedious slog. The lack of variety among enemies contributes to a sense of laziness, with mostly reskinned foes repeating the same predictable skills.

Overall, it's a rather mediocre experience. I've grown so bored, especially with the clunky and self-hating combat, that I can't stand it any longer.
best experience

[h2] God of Hope [/h2]

God of War transcends the boundaries of video game storytelling, delivering a profoundly emotional narrative wrapped in the cloak of intense action. Kratos, once a Spartan warrior seeking vengeance, is transformed into a nuanced and deeply human character, navigating the challenging terrain of fatherhood in the haunting Norse realms. This reinvention of the series doesn't just showcase evolution in gameplay mechanics but a mature, gripping storyline that explores themes of redemption and the complexity of family relationships.
https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=3008760459
The game's technical prowess is a visual feast, with breathtaking landscapes and meticulously crafted details that breathe life into the Norse mythology-inspired world. The single-shot camera technique not only provides a seamless, cinematic experience but serves as a storytelling device, ensuring that players are entirely immersed in the journey of Kratos and Atreus. The combat system, a ballet of brutality, manages to strike a perfect balance between accessibility and depth, making every encounter a thrilling spectacle.
https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=3008672837
God of War stands as a testament to the potential of video games as an art form. It marries heart-wrenching storytelling with exhilarating gameplay, creating an unforgettable odyssey that lingers in the mind long after the controller is set down. From its stunning visuals to the richly developed characters, this game is a masterpiece, redefining the expectations for narrative-driven gaming experiences and earning its place among the industry's greatest achievements.
