Nobody's going to read this anyway, but a piece of advice to any new player for when it's applicable in the final third of the game(super, SUUUPER mild spoiler): either skip niflheim altogether or make your trip as brief as possible. Versus the rest of the game, which is nearly perfect, niflheim is an absolute embarrassment, as though the developers had given that portion of the game to their own kids to work on and complete. It's not due to the difficulty; it's hard enough but I wouldn't say it's unfair in any way. But... oh. MY. GOD. It is boring beyond my ability to describe. It's a level of boring that I could never have even imagined. It was enough to make me start hating this game I had grown to love, not exaggerating in the slightest. Trying to max out armor became such a miserable slog I had to actually say to myself "what am I doing, this is such an utter waste of time" and hurry back to main story, which is fantastic. If you ARE a new player, you won't know what niflheim even means, but I don't think I'm spoiling anything of note when I tell you to STAY AWAY: it's an optional, low quality piece of crap in an otherwise terrific game

God of War, despite my tastes, was incredibly fun and thrilling.

I love the way how it points you directions in the story, all the while making it have this weird illusion of freedom, like as if you were finding "the things to do" yourself, while still making it perfectly clear on what your supposed to do next, It's hard to explain but the game really immerses me so much to the point that it felt like a genuine experience.

If I'm being honest, I really love Kratos, but the lore, the story, the setting- most especially, just isn't my cup of tea, I'm not a huge fan of mythical creatures, enchantresses, Gods and whatever else kind of trope when it comes to games, it's simply my own personal taste, what's even funnier is that while this isn't a "souls-game", it has a slight soulslike factor to it with its combat, which, I, am not a big fan of as well.
It's amazing to me how on paper, all of the things God Of War is, it's not my taste when it comes to games.
Yet I really enjoyed this, it was cinematic, it got me hooked more than anything else, and I must say that this game has one of THE BEST combats- if not, the BEST combat I've ever had in a game, it was a perfect mixture of just, it being simple and easy to learn, yet still having some bits here and there where skill is a must, and a learning curve in your movements, especially finding out different combos and such, I genuinely can't explain how satisfying and fun it is to fight in this game. It makes you feel like a bad-ass every single second yet at the same time, it's not just mindless button mashing as you still have to focus on the combat to truly win those battles that can be easily lost in just two hits.

I have never really played any GoW game before, I've played all three but only a few hours of them, never really diving into the lore, nor even getting halfway of any of these games, so I don't know much about Kratos or the world of GoW, but I know *enough* to create a concept in my head on what is happening.
While all that is, it didn't really confuse me as it felt kind of friendly to newcomers as well, taken in a world where Kratos has, assuming, retired- You're taken into the eyes of a new beginning of some sort, even the "lorebook" was written by Atreus and I find that a neat touch, it's like as if it's meant to be like that, yet while still holding a deep connection with the games before yet, yet still feeling like an entirely new thing now.

One thing that I really like is how the older games were a Hack n' Slash where combat is incredibly easy, and you felt like just an absolute boss whenever you come across anybody, then when I came to this game, I was shocked as I could've swore the combat wasn't like this back then, not even close- I was taken aback at first, thinking that maybe I've made a grave mistake playing this game but immediately fell in love with it, and I like the thought that it's like this now since Kratos wasn't the man who he used to be, making combat, still a badass at it, all-the-while just a little bit more difficult with a few more technicalities, which feels about right for this new older Kratos, unlike before where he was just an absolute killing machine, I really love that.

I can't say I'll ever play any other GoW, a part of me still am not a fan of these kind of things, the gameplay, story, and everything- but this may very well just be one of the best games I've played in a long while.
I decided to not continue any more after the main mission because of it as well, but I hope to someday come back to this game and perfect it, completing every single little task, and gaining everything there is to the game, I feel this game would be so much more enjoyable like that, but I'll leave that for next time.

One greatest thing I could say about this game is its absolute AMAZING sound design, everything from the music, to the voices, to the sound effects are just straight up orgasmic, I could probably just sit down and hack my way through things just for the sake of enjoying the world of it, the sounds really bring out a lot and always do I feel shivers down my spine when I meet with evil, or hell, the World Serpent, all!
It's incredibly fun and makes me all giggly.

This game is absolutely amazing in each and every single way- I can't point out a single thing that I would even change, or even say that is slightly bad, or could've been improved on, it is AMAZING. Period.

There's nothing I can say that I disliked about it, other than it just not being my perfect game due to my tastes.

It's not my cup of tea, but a tea I've enjoyed nonetheless.

This was the first God of War game I played myself, knowing the important parts of the first three games to be able to understand what this games story is built up on. Game play feels really good, fighting feels really polished and enjoyable, and the puzzles using your weapons are really creative and make you think to solve them.  The story is very interesting and having the main cast of characters grow in such unique ways really makes you feel for them, and gets you really invested in what's happening. For people new to the series or experienced in the previous games, I believe that this was an amazing game and definitely worth playing.

"Do not be sorry, be better"

Ceaselessly phenomenal. One of the best narratives in any game I've played accompanied by addictive combat mechanics, customization abilities and equipment, masterful level design, exciting set pieces, unique boss fights, elaborate side missions, and refreshingly faithful depictions of Norse Gods and mythology. The sounds that foes and just about anything in your way make as you obliterate them is akin to ASMR and the character interactions are equally comedic and deeply moving. A console port to PC that works flawlessly, highly recommend (especially on sale) :D

A touching story of father-son bonding with lots of places to explore, things to collect all wrapped up in an insanely satisfying combat system. Quite literally my only complaint is that the lock on is a little finicky but that might just be me not being used to controller gameplay like this. 10/10 experience, can't wait for the sequel to come to steam.

There is a reason this game is so popular.  You are missing out if you haven't played it.  The characters are good and the voice acting is outstanding.  The story is compelling and the gameplay is solid.  There is even a lot of depth for completionists to dig into and enjoy.  Honestly, the only things at all disappointing is how short the main story is (10-15 hours if you are't rushing) and that you are going to have to buy the second game given how much is left hanging.  There is at least 50 hours of game if you get into the side quests and exploring, though, so it's a minor quibble: you definitely get your money's worth with this game.

EDIT: I didn't much like this game as mentioned in my initial review but amended it based on the overall story and the environments and atmosphere. For these reasons I would recommend it but the gameplay mechanics themselves kind of suck, at least for PC. There is a New Play+ feature that lets you continue playing the game (starting over while keeping your gear and stuff) but I don't see the point. It's boring outside the main story. There are a whole set of elements that are useless. Outside of a couple items you craft and maybe some upgrades the entire crafting and resource gathering is beyond pountless. The idea of selling and buying items is also pointless. Outside of the starting gear, there wasnt much of a point to upgrade until mid-game (Tyr Armor) and the late Mist Armor just makes everything easy.



Unpopular opinion, it's a good story wrapped in bad gameplay. First impression was getting a headache from the obnoxious camera shake that as if they tried to provide a POV from a dude with Parkinson's. Seriously hold the perspective steady instead of shaking the screen like a 4 year old who got a hold of their dad's VHS video recorder.

The gameplay mechanics are clunky and most of the enemies are one trick ponies, it's annoying to enter a fight with a new opponent only to basically be one shot because you have no idea how to fight them, only to then be swarmed mid-fight by random respawns of enemies that come from literally no where to ruin the fun.More like reload checkpoint simulastor.

Low on health after a fight with no means of healing? No big deal, just let your character die at the next checkjpoint so you can reload with full health, it's totally not immersion breaking. In fact 99% of the game is immersion breaking. I see now why they have a difficulty specifically for the story. I went in at the second highest because I like a challenge but this is just boring and old. I'll drop it to the lowest and suffer through the boring gameplay to see how the story plays out.

I'm glad I got it during the Steam sale but to be frank, just skip this, you arent missing anything.

Just finished the story, and man that was an amazing experience. I am so glad to have finally gotten around to this game after hearing so much about it. The game has some of the best combat in a game I have experienced in a long time, that is polished but requires practice and skill in order to learn, making you feel competitive and wanting to improve. It is much different than games like Spider-Man or the Arkham series. The greatest thing about the environment/world is the grand scale. It doesn't just look big, it feels big. Everything from the world serpent to the mountain peaks looks amazing, and it feels so expansive despite the game being played on a computer screen. The dialogue and voice acting is amazing, serving the story completely and making all characters, even minor ones, memorable. And the story is engaging, I can say it has been a while since a game has made me want to play it and not do anything else. 

I will need more time to reflect on this experience, but I absolutely recommend playing this game even if you never played the games before. Now, once I am done contemplating on my experience, I think I am going to play Ragnarok and I am really looking forward to it

Very enjoyable game - kept me engaged for much longer than any other games I've played recently. Visually beautiful, story rich, good balance of action, puzzles, and exploration. Just overall well done!

God of War has an engaging and well-written story and this story is the USP of this game. There's never a lull in the plot and it made me keep returning to play the game every day after work. World building is very skilfully done and the rewards and collectibles do not feel lame like they tend to do in some story driven action games. 

The armour system was a mixed bag for me. Even though I kept improving my armour steadily as I progressed through the main story and did a few side quests here and there, I found the higher tier armour to not necessarily look as good or as "legendary" as I had hoped. I wish there was a transmog system where I could put on the highest tier armour pieces I owned with the best stats but visually mix and match the pieces I actually liked the look of. 

The combat gameplay is satisfying and there is a wide swathe of unlockable moves and runic attacks but it does get repetitive very soon due to the narrow enemy variety. I found myself unable to remember most of the advanced moves I unlocked in each of the weapon skill trees and stuck to only a few of them. Things get interesting if you decide to face all bosses of a certain type in the optional side quests. These bosses can and will kick your ass but do not expect amazing rewards after beating them all. Overcoming that challenge is supposed to be the real reward. The main story boss fights are a cakewalk in comparison.

I had no issues with the performance of the game on my PC, not even any frametime stutters which are unfortunately commonplace in modern open-world AAA games on PC. I didn't have even a single crash. The only major miss in this PC port is the lack of customizable FOV. The default FOV in this game is awful and would give me motion sickness during combat until I discovered that I could increase the FOV using a modding tool called Flawless Widescreen. I increased the FOV by 25%, and then everything was good.

Overall I was very pleased with the game entirely because of the story and lore and am looking forward to Ragnarok whenever it gets released on PC. I hope Santa Monica does better with the side quests, armour system and main story boss variety in the next one.

I just finished the game and here is my review.

First and foremost, the narrative is a tour de force. Kratos, once an indiscriminate god-killer, is reborn as a father and mentor to his son, Atreus. The transformation of Kratos from a vengeful god to a more nuanced and complex character is a triumph of character development. The emotional depth and growth exhibited by both Kratos and Atreus throughout the journey are nothing short of extraordinary. The narrative unfolds seamlessly, weaving together Norse mythology with a deeply personal and poignant father-son tale that keeps players emotionally invested from start to finish.

Visually, God of War is a spectacle to behold. The breathtaking landscapes of the Norse realms are rendered with meticulous detail. The character models, especially Kratos and Atreus, are stunningly realistic, and the creature designs are nothing short of awe-inspiring. Every frame feels like a living, breathing painting, immersing players in a world that feels both mythical and grounded.

The combat system is a triumph of fluidity and brutality. Kratos' Leviathan Axe is not just a weapon but an extension of the player's will, with each swing and throw feeling weighty and impactful. The addition of Atreus as a combat ally introduces a strategic layer to the battles, making encounters dynamic and engaging. The upgrade system is robust, allowing players to tailor Kratos' abilities to their preferred playstyle. From epic boss battles to smaller skirmishes, the combat in God of War is a symphony of chaos and control.

The soundtrack elevates the emotional resonance of the game to new heights. The Norse-inspired score complements the game's setting perfectly, enhancing the sense of grandeur and tension. The voice acting as Kratos, is top-notch, bringing the characters to life with nuance and authenticity.

God of War is more than just a game... It's a cinematic odyssey that redefines what is possible in interactive storytelling. It's a testament to the power of video games as an art form, seamlessly blending stunning visuals, compelling narrative, and satisfying gameplay. Santa Monica Studio has not only revived a beloved franchise but has set a new standard for excellence in the gaming industry. God of War is a triumph that will be remembered for years to come.

This God Of War is nothing less than a masterpiece. Never have I ever felt so much like a raging bald man IRL. Fully deserved it''s game of the year award. Hat's off. 

Pros 

- Rewarding and Unbelievable Smooth Combat with a boat load of different play styles to use. 
- Amazing story which set's a different path from the carnage Kratos once caused in Sparta. 
- Amazing and Replayable exploration
- Almost every side quest, Action rewards you for your efforts with XP, Gear or Lore. So practically everything in this game feels like progression or meaningful learning. 
- Great Bosses, Companions and Well Written Characters. 


Cons

- Some enemies are cheap and somewhat Ebola Tier to fight (Revenants, Watchers and oh god.,..the Alfheim Fairy Guards...) 
- BOY lectures you during the middle of heated battles. Just shut the f up kid and summon your wolves.

A Mythical Adventure Comes to PC - God of War Review



As a longtime fan of action games, I was thrilled when "God of War" finally made its way to PC, and it didn't disappoint. This isn't just a simple port; it's a well-optimized experience that brings Kratos' epic journey to life on a new platform.

Graphics and Performance:
First off, the game looks stunning on PC. The graphics are sharp, and the attention to detail in the game's world is impressive. Running on a mid-range setup, I experienced smooth gameplay with very few hiccups. The higher frame rates on PC make the combat even more fluid and satisfying than I remember on consoles.

Story and Characters:
The narrative of "God of War" remains its strongest point. It's a deep, engaging story that masterfully blends action with emotional depth. Watching the relationship between Kratos and Atreus evolve over the course of their journey adds a unique layer to the game that goes beyond typical action titles. Their interactions and growth are as compelling as the battles and exploration.

Gameplay:
The combat system is robust and enjoyable. With a mix of melee attacks, combos, and magical abilities, it offers enough variety to keep things interesting throughout the game. The PC controls are well-mapped, and I found them to be intuitive and responsive, though I occasionally switched to a controller for a more relaxed experience.

Puzzles and Exploration:
Beyond combat, the game offers a good balance of puzzles and exploration. The puzzles are clever without being frustrating, and exploring the different realms provides a nice break from the intensity of the main story quests.

Sound and Music:
The sound design and music are top-notch. The orchestral score elevates the epic feel of the game, and the sound effects add an immersive quality, especially during combat.

Final Thoughts:
"God of War" on PC is an excellent port of an already fantastic game. It combines a compelling story, satisfying combat, and beautiful visuals into a package that feels right at home on PC. Whether you're a fan of the series or new to Kratos' story, this game is a must-play.
Honestly the most fun I've had in a while. I really enjoy the story and how much there is to do. I can't wait to beat the whole game!
Video game Oscar bait, but darn delicious bait. Slow traversal and lack of enemy variety drag down the side content and it does crash every 45 minutes on steam deck though.

Full disclosure: I have not played other God of War games nor is this the kind of thing I usually play. However, I liked this. At first the combat felt very limited but once stuff was upgraded more it became my favorite part of the game. Atreus is a well executed assist character. The puzzles I could go either way.  As the main story is quite long, I feel I paid a fair price for good content, not just grinding or treasure hunting. The mythology and storytelling while traveling are a nice touch to motivate you to explore without becoming bored.

I should note that although it ran smoothly at max graphics on my steam deck, I experienced on average 1 crash an hour. I think it was related to autosaves, but it may also have had to do with the system heating up over time.

7/10 An entertaining use of 50 hrs of my life.

Some games have great game-play, some have amazing stories, and then there are the select few that have both. This is one of those games. I have not played the original God of War trilogy, and I do not know the story, so I did not expect to really be invested in the narrative. But I was wrong. The writing is so damn good! And all the while the game-play keeps being engaging and challenging, without ever feeling unreasonable.  I thought it was awesome. To the point that I actually want to do the content that remains after I finished the main story-line, which is something that I basically never do.

And the world design! Holy crap, its so cool! The Lake of Nine is such an awesome concept and is so fantastically easy to get around, yet always remains diverse and always exciting! Won't say more, for the sake of spoilers, but this game has done something truly special here. 

I think everyone should play this game. Though for those planning on playing it on the steam deck, I would recommend against that. There is a weird memory leak issue that crashed the whole steam deck after about an hour of play time. Do not think it should be considered "verified." It is playable, but the crashing was obnoxious as hell.

After playing the game for more than 50 hours, It has been an incredibly enjoyable experience, and I struggle to explain the feeling of immersing myself in the realm of Nordic gods.

GOOD:

- The graphics are undeniably beautiful, replete with details that align seamlessly with the narrative.

- The combat system is commendable, offering an easily navigable experience even with keyboard controls. 

- The standout feature lies in upgrading armor and diverse weapons. This dynamic keeps the gameplay engaging, necessitating the acquisition of various resources for upgrades and confronting diverse challenges —an endeavor that strikes a balance between being challenging yet not overly difficult. 

- The presence of meaningful rewards, whether from chests or hidden roots, adds significant value to each gaming session.

BAD:

- The enemies faced tend to be somewhat repetitive.
- Despite the richness of the world, the actual story line is surprisingly brief. However, this brevity is offset by the immersive game play, creating the impression that the game is more extensive than its narrative might suggest

Hell yeah, God of War is the best comeback i have ever seen, i always played the series in the ps2 when i was younger, never really finished any game, but the feeling of beating goons up with Kratos never left my imagination, it was just a perfect game for a genre that i never really cared about, then these motherfuckers at Santa Monica come back with a baby made by The Last of Us and Dark Souls combined with one of the most iconic Playstation characters and make one of the best games of all time.

The plot in this game is simple, the characters are complex, and if you know me that's the type of shit that gets me going, right out of the gate you meet Baldur with one of the most exhilarating boss fights i have ever experienced, then boom, you hate that motherfucker, you are aware of the fighting system and you care for your son, now, partner in battle, just a perfect start.

Combat is brutal and skillfull, it takes a while until you feel like the old Kratos again, but when you do get that feeling... it's special, the only bad thing about the combat is the mini-bosses, i think we have like 3 or 4 different minibosses throughout the whole game, thats kinda boring, but its a minor issue in the big scope of the amount of extra content this game brings you.

The feeling of exploration in this game is like no other, you are just sucked in into these little islands and caves and when you are aware again you have lost 3 hours doing side stuff, that is just as good as the main dish, with dragons to free, valkyries to beat and new areas to discover, unlike Red Dead, the open world feels like an extension of the main story in GOW.

So let's break it down, i finished this game, i beat 4 valkyries already, now i have other 4 (5) valkyries to beat, i already did all side quests, and i still have like 65% completion, there is a whole new reign (and i'm pretty sure there is one more) that i just discovered where i'm experiencing a whole new game with a new level of difficulty that is making me question if i should continue because i die every 15min (losing all gathered resources)

I can't wait to touch GOW Ragnarok as i heard the only problem i have with this game has been fixed (variety of minibosses)

When I say I am addicted to this game and whenever I play it's at least 4 hours of it MINIMUM. The exploration, the combat, the LOOT, the S T O R Y, it's all so good and I cannot recommend it enough, if you've been thinking about getting this game or even been on the fence about I can assure you it is so worth it.

HOLY FUCKING SHIT THIS GAME IS AMAZING!!!
First off, the visuals are BEAUTIFUL. Holy shit dude, they are amazing. I feel like I'm really in the world of Midgard, and its surrounding 9 realms.
Second, the voice acting is great. You can truly feel the raw emotion of the characters, especially Kratos. he doesn't speak too much, but when he does, you can really feel it.
third, the combat. Holy fucking shit, god damn. The combat is AMAZING. Its a bit tough to get used to it, but once you do, you can have an absolute BLAST. And that just improves once you get the blades of chaos, getting a good combo on an enemy is an absolutely AWESOME thing to do, throwing an enemy up in the air and then pulling them down with your chains, then pulling yourself closer to them to do MASSIVE damage, and then boxing them with close range blades, absolute ecstasy, thats what that is.
and finally, the story. I'm not going to say much, because I can't say much. And thats not saying that theres no story, what it means is that there is SO MUCH GOOD FUCKING STORY, that I can't even describe it.
Overall, 10/10 game. i recommend it to all gamers looking for a good, story rich, open world rpg.

God of War (2018) is a masterpiece. Santa Monica Studio has taken the series in a bold new direction, and the result is a breathtaking experience that surpassed all my expectations. Graphically, the game is a showcase of testing PC's capabilities and I recommend it as the baseline . The environments are stunningly detailed, from the towering peaks of Midgard to the dark realms of Helheim. To the Eleven home of Alfheim, the challenges of Muspelheim and Niflheim. The character models, especially Kratos,Atreus, and cant forget Mimir exhibit an incredible level of realism.The narrative is a triumph. Kratos' journey through Norse mythology is not just a spectacle of violence; it's a deeply emotional and poignant story of fatherhood, redemption, and the weight of one's past. The addition of Atreus as a companion adds a layer of complexity to the gameplay and tugs at the heartstrings with their evolving father-son dynamic. Which reminds me of me and my Father who I've never been super close with but have now. Combat is a revelation. The Leviathan Axe is a joy to wield, providing a satisfying mix of power and finesse. The shift to a more methodical combat style is a welcome change, requiring strategy and skill rather than button-mashing. The variety of enemies and the challenging boss battles keep the combat fresh and engaging throughout. The open-world design enhances the sense of exploration. Midgard feels alive with secrets, puzzles, and side quests that add depth to the overall experience. The interconnected realms and the lore scattered throughout the game kept me invested which i'm almost 100% with the game.I appreciate the pacing of the game. It seamlessly weaves together moments of intense action, exploration, and quieter, character-driven scenes. The musical score is exceptional, complementing the emotional beats of the story and the epic scale of the journey. God of War (2018) isn't just a game; it's an interactive masterpiece that sets a new standard for storytelling in the medium. Whether you're a longtime fan of the series or a newcomer, this game is an absolute must-play it's honestly one of the greatest games/story's ever.God i cant wait for Ragnarök. 10/10

Intensely enjoyable RPG experience with excellent story, mechanics, characters, writing, upgrades, weapons, bosses, enemies, and progression.

The only complaint I can muster is that the final boss is really really easy if you finish all of the side content first. This isn't because you are upgraded super high (though that indeed adds to it), but because the side content is FAR more difficult than the final boss. The most difficult boss in the game is not the final boss by far, and the boss in question is one of the most difficult I have experienced in any game. By the time you return to the main story line your skills have increased greatly and the final boss becomes really trivial, though the spectacle is awesome.

Beyond this slight change in expectation, the entire game is masterful and I can only wait impatiently for the next installment to come to PC.

Thank you developers for this amazing experience!

Great fighting style, great lore, great implementation of Norse mythology. Highly recommend this reboot to a classic game.

Great story, although certain elements require more development, since the relationship between Kratos and Atreus was well explored. Those elements that I am not going to mention for spoiler reasons can break immersion.

The combat system, ironically, is not very strong, after being what defined God of War, along with its spectacular, brutal and exaggerated scenes.

The closing of the game was a bit disappointing, especially because they make a basic writing error: if you show a gun, the gun must be fired. Obviously I'm not talking about this literally, God of War is not a shooter (although it can be if you try hard and have enough patience).

The RPG systems are fine, nothing incredible or new. I give, however, not two, but my 4 thumbs up to the fact that the game is one continuous shot, without cuts or loading screens.

The dialogue is wonderful and the voice artists were amazing.

If you're looking for fast-paced action, this may not be the right game, as you'll few challenging situations, even on the highest difficulty. However. If you want a good story, similar to watching a long movie, this may be what you want.

8 out of 10 in my opinion. I await the release of Ragnarok for PC.

[i][b]God of War[/b][/i] is an incredible experience from start to finish. It doesn’t overstay its welcome, it doesn’t overwhelm with things to do, and it keeps its narrative as the focus throughout.

[h1][b]Gameplay[/b][/h1]
The core gameplay has you playing from an over-the-shoulder perspective as you hack, slash & bash your way through foes in front of you. Off to your side, your son Atreus will assist in combat when and where he can. Warning you of incoming projectiles or attacks from behind, or if an enemy risks afflicting Kratos with an ailment. Outside of combat, you’ll be running, jumping, climbing and solving puzzles as you progress through the game’s world in a mostly-linear fashion.

[h1][b]Story[/b][/h1]
The story is, simply put, incredible. Kratos must venture forth to the highest summit in all of Midgard to spread the ashes of his wife Faye, as this was her last wish. Accompanying him on his journey is their son Atreus, whom along the way must learn to become stronger, smarter and more independent as the world before him is unrelenting and unforgiving.

Making their way to the mountaintop sounds, at first, like a very middling story. However, this adventure quickly tests them and forces them to depend on one-another, something Kratos had never before had to contend with. Throughout their journey, the two encounter many interesting characters, and the world begins to brim with life. Both with the characters they meet, and the tales they soon learn, discovering the history of the world which they must call home.

As a narrative, the game works as a pseudo-reboot of the original series, working independently whilst also maintaining implicit and explicit ties to Kratos’ past. You do not need to play the original games to appreciate the story, but for those who have, it will be an even richer experience.

[h1][b]Performance[/b][/h1]
The game looks & runs incredibly well, I’m happy to say. Its configuration options leave little to be desired, and it even has presets for running the game in “Original” graphics mode, which uses the same settings as the PS4 version of the game. I was able to run the game on Ultra with an RTX 3090 and maintain 120 FPS at 2560x1440, with no hitches, stutters or dips throughout. To accomplish this, I set DLSS to Quality, using the latest (at the time) version of 2.5.1. This image reconstruction looks better than native, and the performance boost is modest, taking me from 90-100 FPS, to a locked 120.

Performance scales excellently too, allowing me to reach over 200 FPS if certain settings are turned down. Load times are nearly nonexistent after boot, and the game plays incredibly smoothly.

[h1][b]Conclusion[/b][/h1]
Overall, [i][b]God of War[/b][/i] is an amazing experience from start to finish. It only takes ~50 hours to complete all that the game has to offer (including all achievements) and doesn’t overstay its welcome. The combat is fantastic, the boss fights are fun, the challenges are fair, the performance is excellent, and the story is amazing.

For those who are comfortably with over-the-shoulder games, this is a must-play!

[h1]Pros[/h1]
[list]
    [*]Incredible story with rich detailed environments and dialogue; main story is self-contained from side-content and does not require adept understanding of gameplay mechanics to enjoy the experience
    [*]Very deep lore that expands and centres on Norse mythological gods and the establishment of them in the story, the Greek gods/world does also exist but is not the focal
    [*]Graphics and animations are smooth, very rare stutters/lags, gameplay is incredibly responsive and sound design is perfection
    [*]Skill trees and gearing are very linear and do not require heavy investment to succeed in the world
    [*]Combat is easy to learn & difficult to master, once you play around with different inputs you find interesting combos to chain together
    [*]Runic attacks, pommels, and talismans can make for interesting combos that accelerate in certain damage types
    [*]Kratos, Atreus, & Mimir are a fantastic well-designed cast of protagonists
    [*][b]Brok & Fucking Gratitude {Best Pair}[/b]
[/list]
[h1]Cons[/h1]
[list]
    [*]Delete revenants from the game
    [*]Certain enemies input read where they dash off-screen causing lock-off to break, its not the worse until they hit you because of it
    [*]Need more mystic gateways in Midgard
    [*]Missables (or bugs), there are certain pieces of content that are missable, these include: certain pieces of equipment that are not acquired in limited story zones, Mimir's tales, and labor miscounts
[/list]

"God of War (2018)" delivers an experience that reshapes the iconic franchise. Kratos now ventures through Norse realms, his story deepened by a rich, character-driven narrative as he ventures forth with his son Atreus.

The combat system, fluid and engaging, gains a new level of precision and responsiveness on PC. Visually, the game is a marvel, with enhanced graphics that make its mythical world more immersive. 

The PC version maintains the core essence of the original while offering improvements both big and small that cater to both series veterans and newcomers. This isn't just a port; it's a masterful adaptation, showcasing how a legendary game can be transformed into an even better game for the master of all platforms.

[b]+[/b] : Story and Setting.

[b]+/-[/b] : Epic but Bullet-Spongy Combat.

[b]-[/b] : Constant Looting and RPG Elements.

[h1][b]God of War 2018[/b][/h1]

[b]Rating: 6/10 - Fine[/b]

This game commits the possibly worst sin any game can commit; it's boring. Just plain boring. The game is filled with tedious walking and talking sections that really don't do much beside delivering dialogue, a lot of which just feels so damn awkward. Combat feels clunky and is, due to the minuscule amount of enemy variety, just as boring as the rest of the game which just consists of the most brain dead "puzzles" and walking sections where a story pretending to be great is delivered to you with voice acting way too good for it. The entire story is based on emotions caused by the death of a character I simply don't give a shit about because I didn't fucking know her. And you never really get to know her because the writers seemed to have forgotten the first rule of writing: [b]Show, don't tell[/b]. And then you're constantly annoyed with needless comments from that annoying, worthless little wretch Atreus whose entire point in the game seems to be to be annoying. I get it that he is supposed to be a grieving son, but it's still annoying to see him do and/or say some stupid shit every 10 seconds. This drags down a story based on emotional investment I can't have even more. It still has it's moments, features some good characters - even though all of them are introduced with terrible pacing, meaning that about 3 seconds after meeting them you're already buddy buddy with them because fuck getting to know someone. The only outstanding things about this game are the voice acting and the soundtrack. Just a boring slog.

What an incredible video game. 

God of War (2018) is a phenomenally crafted piece of entertainment that blends the believable father-son story with a breathtaking soundtrack and very good graphics. 

This is the first God of War game I have personally played, and though I have always been aware of the series, this was my first jump into a journey with Kratos. As a newcomer, I felt that the game did a great job getting me accustom to the world with its lore explanations, character explanations, and clear indications of the end goal. The game did a surprisingly remarkable job at making me care for Kratos as a character, as he's always been known as a killing machine in the other games, as far as I'm aware, with nothing else really going on around him; so this was very pleasant to see. I feel the whole story holds up really well in fact.

As already mentioned, Bear Mccreary's compositions are masterfully constructed, with the main theme stuck in my head! 

95% of this game was an amazing time, but there were some gripes.

My main gripe is with how the game handles combat. For the most part, it's extremely satisfying to perform all the gruesome moves that Kratos has at his disposal, however, there are times where I felt I was unfairly robbed of health due to some jankyness; and I feel this is primarily the fault of the camera - it often feels way too close to Kratos, leading to a lot of times where combat can feel incredibly claustrophobic. I feel the devs knew this was an issue as well as they opt to have a reticle around Kratos that adapts colours depending when enemies would attack Kratos, and the quick-turn button. And while these are useful features, the reticle, in my opinion, could have been greatly aided by a further drawn back camera so that the player can see more around them, and the quick-turn being a D-pad button feels really awkward to use during intense fights, leading me to rarely ever using it.

I also felt that the last hour or two hurt the game's pacing. A lot of things you do towards getting to Jötunheim just feel like roadblocks for the sake of padding out the game's runtime when it could have easily wrapped up a lot sooner than it did. 

And lastly, while it didn't happen much during my playthrough, I did encounter 3 game crashes that sort of took me out the experience a little.

Apart from these small issues that I had, like I said, this was an incredible time from start to end. Santa Monica did an incredible job on this game, and I'm certainly going to be jumping back in very soon to complete some more side quests and upgrade my gear!

Incredible story, fun combat, but there are a handful of complaints.

For starters, Revenants are incredibly annoying enemies. But that's only a minor gripe.
The real issues with this game are primarily centered around the absolutely suffocating quantities of collectibles and backtracking paired with all the grinding required to get some of the late game gear (and the Muspelheim grinding is easily the absolute worst). Not to mention the disproportionate amount of gear you get compared to upgrade materials. 

Though on more positive notes;
The final boss and ending are phenomenal, rewarding, and fun. Another highlight of the game is the banter. I love listening to Atreus and (The) Head talk about Norse Myhtos and stories (even though they have taken a fair number of liberties with it). Overall, I'd rate this game a 7/10

I had a great time playing God of War and ended up spending the time to 100% the game on its standard difficulty. I'm sure that there are games out there with better combat systems or more detailed open worlds, but God of War stuck out to me because unlike other games, there's really nothing to gripe about. The combat and mechanics are fleshed out and fun without being insanely hard to learn. Builds have variety but aren't extremely complicated. Puzzles are engaging and often take a second to think about, but nothing is so complicated that the average gamer would need a walk through. Where God of War actively shines, however, is in its story. This game finds a balance that other games struggle to achieve, with a story that is compelling without being convoluted or overly lengthy. The cast is small, allowing each character to be detailed and three dimensional. Ending is intriguing and has made me excited to play Ragnarok when it is finally ported to PC. Overall I consider this one of the best games I have played.

Just got this game on sale after looking into it a bit. Having never played the PS versions, this is now easily within my TOP FIVE all time games. First it looks amazing on a decent rig. I'm running an RTX 4070 and 32 GB RAM, and it easily hits 100 fps in Ultra settings at 1440p. The graphics alone made this worth the purchase at sale price. But the combat and the story take it to the next level. The combat is so satisfying and hard hitting, especially with a subwoofer near your feet and controller feedback. Play this game LOUD or with headphones. I'm using a controller so can't speak to how it performs on keyboard and mouse. I only had one crash/freeze in about 20 hrs of play so far, and that was during the first dragon battle, which is INTENSE. I turned of DLSS and haven't had any other issues, and it may have just been coincidence. I can't get over the scale of the game and how everything makes this huge, muscular main character look tiny. The camera angles are excellent, and the art direction is top notch. If you're even close to being on the fence, just buy it..on sale preferably, but it's worth every penny of full price as well.

God Of War 2018 is a stunning single player open world although very linear experience set in ancient Scandinavia focused the realm of Midgard, With unreal world building and in depth lore and character building focused around the main protagonist Kratos and his son Atreus. This incredible game boasts about 30 hours of campaign gameplay where you will learn all about this world and its characters featuring a huge roster of historic figures including many famous Nordic Gods. This game kept me glued to my screen from start to completion unlike many other games I have played before.
What the game lacks in certain mechanics it more than makes up for in an incredible story, In depth lore, Lovable characters, An incredible sense of adventure and it will make you feel like a real god! This game will catch all fans the RPG, Open world genre hook line and sphincter!

God of war is amazing! I played the original trilogy and was excited to finally play this game now that it's on PC. There is something about this game that the creators did so right, it brings out an anger in me while playing it, the good kind of anger and it manifests at the same time that Kratos rages and then beats the snot out of the enemy during a provoking cut scene. 

The puzzles are unique and sometimes had me stumped sometimes a little longer than I would like to admit, but it was never too hard or easy of a puzzle. The designs of the puzzles feel fun to complete especially when the two brain cells finally get it and everything falls into place.

The graphics look great, and the environment is fun to explore. I was always happy to come back and revisit old areas when I earned new weapons that opened previously locked chests and paths. The story is compelling and it always felt like I had a good reason for what I was doing next, but also giving plenty of chances to go side questing without seeming like it didn't make sense.

The weapons are fun to use and satisfying when you get a kill animation or a perfect parry. The game also allows you to build for straight damage, stun, or runic attacks which is nice to have the custom ability that wasn't seen in the original trilogy.

I think the best part of God of War are the characters, especially the relationship between Kratos and Atreus. The conversations between the two feel like real people with real problems and not a poorly written script. We also see great character development not only in both Kratos and Atreus, but also smaller side characters such as the Dwarven brothers that makes the progress throughout the story all the more satisfying.

A couple of minor downsides I feel that are worth mentioning is that first, if you're not using a controller and are rebinding controls for mouse and keyboard, there are certain buttons such as 2 that aren't initially bound to anything because it's for something later in the game, but if you rebind something to one of these buttons it resets all of your bindings without telling you what isn't working or why. This isn't game breaking but it was a little frustrating when I was adjusting bindings in the beginning. Another minor problem I had is that the field of view is not adjustable, it's pretty close and you can mostly only see over Kratos' right shoulder, limiting your view a bit. A friend says it's to add to the challenge, but to me if that's the case why isn't it at least an option to adjust it just like the difficulty setting? Again these are just minor complaints I think were at least worth a mention and do not break or ruin the game.

The game is overall amazing and I Highly recommend this game especially for people that enjoy story driven games with compelling characters and also wish they could drop a skyscraper onto their enemies when things don't go their way. Can't wait to play Ragnarok!

Just didn't mesh with me. Felt like a walking simulator since the pace is so slow and the characters, at least at face value seem really boring. The combat is good but it's not like it's any better than most action/souls-like games these days, and it's simply too rare. For the most part you're just doing linear climbing, travelling, sailing, and 'solving' puzzles that are so simple a four year old could figure them out, but to just make the whole experience even more infuriating the characters will just tell you the answer before you even begin the puzzle. For the first few you're like "ok, it's just the tutorial so fair enough" but then they just keep doing it! 

My whole time with this game just felt like I was waiting to get to the good bit. After about 13 hours I just don't think there's going to be a good bit. Way too many boring cutscenes where no character establishing or development occurs. Excited boy is excited, grumpy dad is grumpy. I'm sure there's a good story somewhere in the game, but I don't have the patience to have it drip fed to me while having my time wasted with countless sections of slow pointless 'puzzles', climbing, walking, etc. 

Might give it another chance at some point, we'll see.

Not much replay value, especially due to story & puzzles being already known.

Released in 2018, the latest installment in the God of War franchise, simply titled "God of War," has left an indelible mark on the gaming landscape. Developed by Santa Monica Studio and published by Sony Interactive Entertainment, this reimagining of the iconic series transcends its hack-and-slash roots, offering players a deeply emotional and immersive experience. In this essay, we will explore the various elements that contribute to the brilliance of God of War, from its captivating narrative and character development to its breathtaking visuals and innovative gameplay mechanics.

Compelling Narrative and Character Development:

At the heart of God of War's success lies its compelling narrative, a departure from the Greek mythology that characterized previous installments. The game introduces players to a more mature and contemplative Kratos, the Spartan warrior, who now finds himself in the rich tapestry of Norse mythology. The decision to explore a new pantheon allows for a fresh narrative perspective, making the story accessible to both long-time fans and newcomers alike.

The central theme of the game revolves around Kratos' relationship with his son, Atreus. The emotional depth and complexity of their bond elevate the narrative beyond the typical action-adventure fare. Kratos, once a vengeful god, is now a father trying to navigate the challenges of parenthood while grappling with his violent past. The growth and development of these characters throughout the journey lend a poignant and relatable dimension to the narrative, resonating with players on a profound level.

The storytelling is masterfully woven into the gameplay, with seamless transitions between cinematic cutscenes and player-controlled sequences. The emotional weight of the narrative is further amplified by the stellar performances of the voice cast, particularly Christopher Judge as Kratos and Sunny Suljic as Atreus. The result is a narrative experience that transcends the boundaries of conventional gaming, evoking emotions and investment rarely seen in the medium.

Breathtaking Visuals and Artistic Design:

God of War sets a new standard for visual excellence in gaming. The game's graphics, powered by the stunning capabilities of the PlayStation 4 hardware, deliver a visual spectacle that is nothing short of breathtaking. The attention to detail in character models, environments, and atmospheric effects is a testament to the dedication of the development team.

The world of Midgard, inspired by Norse mythology, is rendered with meticulous care. From the towering peaks of the Nine Realms to the serene beauty of the Lake of Nine, each locale is a visual feast that immerses players in a mythical realm. The dynamic camera, which maintains a single shot throughout the entire game, enhances the cinematic quality of the experience, allowing players to appreciate the intricacies of the world without interruption.

The artistic design extends beyond the visual to the auditory, with a hauntingly beautiful score composed by Bear McCreary. The music complements the tone and setting of the game, heightening emotional moments and adding a layer of depth to the overall experience. The marriage of visual and auditory elements in God of War creates an immersive world that captivates players from the moment they embark on Kratos and Atreus' journey.

Innovative Gameplay Mechanics:

God of War not only excels in narrative and visuals but also introduces innovative gameplay mechanics that redefine the action-adventure genre. The combat system undergoes a significant overhaul, shifting from the fixed, cinematic camera angles of previous entries to an over-the-shoulder perspective. This change brings a newfound intimacy to the combat, allowing players to feel the weight and impact of each strike.

The Leviathan Axe, Kratos' primary weapon in this installment, introduces a satisfying and versatile combat experience. Players can throw the axe at enemies, recalling it to their hand with a satisfying thud, or engage in close-quarters combat with a combination of light and heavy attacks. The seamless integration of Atreus into the combat adds an additional layer of strategy, as players can command him to shoot arrows, providing crowd control and opening up new tactical possibilities.

The game's progression system is well-balanced, offering a variety of upgrades for both Kratos and Atreus. From new combat skills and magic abilities to weapon enhancements, the progression system encourages players to experiment with different playstyles while maintaining a sense of character growth and empowerment.

Open-World Exploration and Side Quests:

God of War introduces a more expansive and interconnected world compared to its linear predecessors. The Lake of Nine serves as a central hub, connecting various realms and offering opportunities for exploration. The decision to adopt an open-world structure enhances the sense of adventure, as players can undertake side quests, discover hidden secrets, and encounter optional bosses while progressing through the main story.

The side quests, often interwoven with Norse mythology and lore, contribute to the richness of the game world. These quests are not mere diversions but provide additional context to the narrative, fleshing out the world and its inhabitants. The open-world design encourages players to engage with the game beyond its main storyline, fostering a sense of discovery and curiosity.

Conclusion:

In conclusion, God of War stands as a pinnacle of modern gaming, seamlessly blending a compelling narrative, breathtaking visuals, innovative gameplay mechanics, and an expansive world. The evolution of Kratos as a character, the emotional depth of the narrative, and the exploration of Norse mythology contribute to a gaming experience that transcends its genre. Santa Monica Studio's meticulous attention to detail and commitment to excellence have resulted in a masterpiece that not only satisfies long-time fans of the series but also sets a new standard for the potential of storytelling in video games. God of War is not merely a game; it is an immersive journey that leaves an indelible mark on the hearts of those who experience its brilliance.

God of War stands as a breathtakingly crafted masterpiece, seamlessly blending captivating visuals with a well-paced narrative. I found myself deeply engrossed in the rich dialogues, intrigued by the intricate lore surrounding the characters, and thoroughly tested in the realm of combat. For those yearning to immerse themselves in a gaming experience that truly captivates, look no further. Boasting over 22+ hours of gameplay for just the main story and an array of side quests also offered, there's an abundance of content to explore at your leisure. I highly recommend ramping up the difficulty if you're an ardent gamer, as even with a few challenging moments, I only faced a couple of deaths during my playthrough. In summary, a truly exceptional experience.

"God of War" 2018 is like an epic journey through a world of mythical gods and monsters, and let me tell you, it's mind-blowingly awesome!

You play as Kratos, this super tough warrior dude with a cool axe, who's on an adventure with his son, Atreus. The best thing about this game? The battles are insanely cool! Kratos fights giant creatures and gods using his axe and bare hands, and it's all so intense and action-packed.

But wait, the coolest part? The story! It's like a movie you play. Kratos and Atreus travel through this amazing world based on Norse mythology, meeting all sorts of crazy characters and facing mind-blowing challenges. And their relationship throughout the game is so touching and well-done, you'll totally feel connected to them.

The graphics and world in "God of War" are out of this world! Seriously, it's like you're in a painting. The forests, the mountains, even the monsters look insanely real! And the way the game's camera follows you everywhere, giving you this cinematic experience? It's genius!

The game's puzzles and exploration are super fun too. You get to solve puzzles that really make you think, and the whole world is filled with secrets and treasures waiting for you to discover.

In a nutshell, "God of War" 2018 is a masterpiece! It's got jaw-dropping fights, an emotional story, stunning graphics, brain-teasing puzzles, and a world you'll want to explore forever. If you're into action-packed adventures with a touch of emotion and mind-blowing visuals, this game is an absolute MUST-play! Seriously, it's one of the best games out there!

Yes.

Positive: 
- The controls are great. 
- The menus are clean. 
- Video Sequences are very nice and can be paused. 
- Graphics are fantastic after tweaking settings. *After turning off AMD FSR 2.0 all looked great for my system. I also used 
 G-sync and mostly Ultra settings with Shadows and reflections on high. 
- Navigation is great for most of the game. 
- The story is very good.  
- Difficulty settings can be changed. 
- Touch of humor at times. 
- Boss fights are split into stages allowing you to save and continue if you die. 
- The game often gives you tips or warnings if it senses you are lost.  
- Great ending.  

 

Negative: 
- No audio narration in the codex journal. 
- Some of the combat sequences felt over the top for my liking. *Think Matrix.  
- Limitations where you can walk or jump. 
- Keeping up with button combinations for attack upgrades is a bit frustrating. 
- You can’t swing your axe when holding the shield.  
- Parts of the game make you play through certain areas again which is a little repetitive.  

 
Conclusion: 

During the first quarter of the game all I could think was “Why would anyone want to play anything else?”, it just felt that good. 

The high imagination level is well appreciated, leaving a lot of memorable areas and scenes. There are vivid colors, organic elements and clever mechanical puzzles. 

The only real drawbacks for me were somewhat minor. There was some repetitiveness about halfway through which left me a little frustrated. Otherwise, no real complaints. 

Compared to Skyrim, it’s nowhere near as dark. Instead, it provides more life, vibrancy and some human emotion.  

I am very pleased with God of War. The dynamic between father and son felt natural and believable. This combined with a likable story helped carve out one heck of an experience.

 

RECOMMENDED   9.5/10

The combat mechanics are very well implemented and you constantly unlock new moves that you can integrate into the battles.

The story is well written, but it doesn't get very deep which is fine for this kind of game. Also the game doesn't overstay its welcome by being padded out with filler content. There is one optional 'grindy' area in the game, but even that doesn't feel too bad.

Overall a very good action title with solid exploration and a great presentation. Recommended.

This is an action RPG like Diablo, not a skill-based action game. Gear score is worth more than skill, and higher difficulties are intended for higher gear score. You will have a lot more fun with the game with that in mind. If you hit a wall, just grind materials for better armor, or play on a lower difficulty to lower the levels of the enemies.Do not mistake this for a simple story-mode game, it just acts like one for the first few hours! It is replayable, it has tons of content and it is fun.

I've spent years waiting to play this and as someone who grew up playing on the different iterations of Playstations its really nice being able to play a staple of the gaming industry like God of War on PC. So here is my review for the game:

10/10

This game is seriously a home run. Watching Kratos develop from this extremely gruff character that has seen (and caused) immense tragedy to developing into a father who, although still rough, actually shows a tender side is great character development. Its crazy to me that after years of fighting in the Greek pantheon they were able to make such a smooth transition to an entirely new area with a new feel while also still keeping many of the things that we loved about the original series. The story is amazing, graphics look great, game play is smooth, and I never felt bored. A true masterclass from Sony, well done.

This game is extremely fun, but please do not set it to the hardest difficulty unless you're extremely sweaty or you have the patience of a monk. I'm already 51.4 hours in and I'm just now at the fight with Modi and Magni. Overall though the game is insanely fun and the weapons, abilities, and whatnot are really cool. 

The combat is kind of annoying sometimes, especially while playing on the hardest difficulty. Each enemy requires a certain strategy for defeating them however, more often than not, you'll have to constantly fight more than one type of enemy. Each one requiring a different strategy than the other. While you're focusing on an Ogre, for example, 7 Reavers just destroy you in 1 hit. 

It's annoying, on the hardest difficulty at least, but the game overall is very enjoyable and easy to get lost in.

Hearing amazing reviews and being a fan of the series, I finally played GoW, and I was incredibly disappointed.

Gameplay-wise the game is great, I enjoyed the quasi open world, the fighting system and the RPG-elements, so if you are mostly interested in gameplay, the game won't disappoint, but if you have a great expectation from the story and from the father-son relationships this game will probably greatly disappoint you, like it did for me.

They changed the whole camera angle to give the game a cinematic feeling, and if one's is playing the game by paying attention to the story, one will be greatly let down. So many plot holes and inconsistencies. For example, it feels like Atreus is not a product of love but a mistake of a broken condom. How the fück did Kratos started a family but has zero familial bond with his son? What was he doing for 8 years, was he an absent father? It certainly feels like it. The family dynamics are very weird, and they are not explained at all. I don't understand who can play this game and enjoy the father-son's relationship.  His son literally raised his hand at his father at one point, what is completely unconscionable for anyone from a decent family. The relationship feels more like a story about trashy drunken low-class people rather than a story about gods and mythical beings, there is nothing epic about all characters in the story. If the original series had that Greek tragedy and mythology vibe to it, here we have a story about trashy scumbags with superpowers. Something like [i]The Boys[/i].

TLDR: 
A playstation game full of a lot of "Cinematic" slop (because games are desperate to be movies now), but the gameplay designers mostly saved the game from being complete garbage. There are a few issues with gameplay like lack of enemy variety, bad arena designs along with the camera etc. On a first time playthrough some of the slower parts aren't as bad if you care about the story, but the "platforming" and world exploration could have been done in a less time wasting way, and they should have had more combat and less pretty environment sections. Combat is easy to learn hard to master and there's a lot of extra content in Niflheim / Musphelheim if you really want along with Valkeyrie fights. Combat is good 

What are some good things about this game? 
-The combat is MOSTLY fun and you can do very little or a lot with it depending on your skill / familiarity with the game 
-The story is good for the most part and kept me engaged 
-Graphics are fine 
-There's a lot of extra optional content for people who aren't normies playing this on "Give me a story :nerdemoji:" difficulty, yes that's the name for easy 
	-Valkeyrie fights are challenging (rage inducing) but also fun to finally beat 

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
What are some bad things? 

-MUSPHELHEIM AND NIFLHEIM ARE FUCKING ABSOLUTE trash. They're just annoying slogs to play. Musphelheims challenges are fucking painful to finally do and niflheim just throws a shitton of annoying enemies at you while you walk around collecting shit. I might enjoy niflheim more now that I'm better at combat, but probably not. 

-The intro is painfully slow 
-There's a lot of cinematic trash like :
	-Slow AUTO CLIMBING THAT TAKES ZERO skill and is literally only there to waste your time 
	-Slow boat rowing to get to scattered little islands 
	-You can't jump and jumping "puzzles" you just spam jump until Kratos auto jumps for you 
	-THE CAMERA STYLE IS FUCKING TRASH and does not fit the gameplay. Another one of the decisions that Corey Barlog made that I completley disagree with. 
	
-The open world is empty and pretty scaled back from other open world games, there's not a whole lot for you to do in the open world 

-The game should have been quicker. What I mean by quicker is that movement should have been faster, the climbing sections should not even exist. There should have been more combat between spaces. The game is too slow for being a god of war game
	
-There is not enough combat during the main story and in the open world environments, it almost feels like you're walking around oepning chests 80% of the time and then 		you get to fight the other 20%, maybe less

	
-The ENEMY VARIETY is absolute fucking trash. Not only that, but some of these enemies are just painfully annoying to fight. There is a whole type of enemy that you 	literally cannot melee fight. You HAVE to throw your axe at it  and slowly very slowly chip away at it's heatlh while also making sure some other crackhead zombie 	doensn't fist you from behind while you're not paying attention. 
	(I wasn't even aware of this enemy behavior until I looked at the codex finally)

			-To explain this point further: There are like 7 different enemies with COMPLETELY different behavior that look nearly identical. (The draugr) This is 				fucking abyssmal game design and it lead to so much confusion when I was first playing the game. 
			
			-Barely any actual boss fights, they reuse the troll enemy multiple times in place of real bosses. I don't care that they "ran out of time" the game 				still suffers. They should have delayed the game. And no, I don't buy the idea that a boss takes a year and a half to make I don't know why I 				keep hearing that from game directors. 

-The game has very weird pacing. You go from beating encounters easily during the main story to having weirdly difficult fights that are just artificially difficult because there's like 5 enemies throwing projectiles at you one after the other at different times 

-The RPG mechanics are fucking annoying. (Which is why I decided on this latest playthrough to just download someones new game plus save, I do not want to have to worry about grinding for mats to upgrade shit, I wanted to focus on getting better at combat) This one confuses me, becuase I like loot games like diablo, and I always say they should combine looting mechanics with skill based mechanics, but it really doesn't work. At least not here. I do not want to have to go around loot hunting and loot farming to level up my armor just so that I can survive some damage. In a game like this, the focus should be on improving at the combat and mastering it, not worrying about if you need to have more vitality enchantments. I don't even know why it's here honestly. The old games were hack and slash, not looting action rpg's. If they want stuff to find in chests / in the open world and from bosses, make stuff cosmetic. There's also already the runic attacks that you can find, and health / rage upgrades.\

-I honestly don't think they did Kratos enough justice in the game. He's very quiet most of the time even when he's angry. There's not very many badass moments with him, it just feels like they missed out on some fan service in the game. The intro / outro fights do a good job of making him feel badass, (mainly the intro fight) I just wish we could have seen more of that. 

-I'm tired of projectile enemies that spawn with no indiciation in a far corner of the arena that I can't even SEE BECUASE OF THE CINEMATIC CAMERA, that throw shit at you while you're distracted with enemies you can actually hit. I do not care if you're trying to incentivize me to throw the axe, fuck off. They take like 5 - 7 axe throws to kill on higher difficulties and it's UNFUN. If you want something designed to make me throw the axe, make it a UNIQUE ENEMY THAT DOESN'T LOOK THE SAME AS THE OTHERS and isn't a fucking sponge. Also, next time make the axe throw attack options not weak as fuck. One of them makes you hold the aim key while it SLOWLY has dots appear signifying how many times it will hit. It feels sluggish and slow and I feel like it's too dangerous to use. The risk outweighs the reward massively, because it hardly does any damage. Perhaps it does decent stun damage or something? maybe it's useful if all of the enemies in the room are far away, but the point still stands. 
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------


----------------------------------------------
Final thoughts: 
If you're going to play this and want to enjoy your time with it get a notebook / piece of paper and write down things like the button combos as you unlock them so that you have smoething to reference quickly without having to read through the attacks individually in the menu. Otherwise you'll probably forget most of them even exist, at least I did. Also, when you come across a new enemy, try to read the codex to see what bullshit you have to deal with, it will make your life so much easier and less frustrating. Try not to chuck your controller at the wall when a draugr comes up to you and you try to hit it multiple times only to do no damage to it and have half your hp gone in 5 seconds. If there is some stupid bastard on a platform throwing projectiles at you, do your best to prioritize the fucker and spam arrows / throw your axe at it while trying to avoid other enemies. Yes this review is mostly negative, because I have a lot of complaints about this game and it doesn't get enough criticism from people soyjacking over it becuase "omg it's so mature and cinematic"

"God of War" stands as an unparalleled masterpiece that redefines the action-adventure gaming genre. Developed by Santa Monica Studio, this game is a testament to exceptional storytelling, immersive gameplay, and breathtaking visuals.

At its core, "God of War" is a narrative-driven journey that follows the gripping tale of Kratos, a tormented and complex character, as he navigates through the realms of Norse mythology alongside his son, Atreus. The game showcases a remarkable evolution of Kratos, transforming him from a vengeful god into a father figure striving to impart wisdom while dealing with his haunted past.

One of the game's most remarkable features is its seamless integration of storytelling and gameplay. The single-shot camera technique immerses players in a cinematic experience, creating an uninterrupted flow that enhances the emotional depth of the narrative. The bond between Kratos and Atreus is beautifully portrayed, fostering not only a compelling dynamic between the characters but also influencing gameplay mechanics and puzzle-solving elements.

The combat system in "God of War" is both brutal and sophisticated. It combines visceral melee combat with RPG elements, offering a diverse range of weapons, skills, and abilities that players can upgrade throughout their journey. Each encounter feels intense and rewarding, encouraging strategic thinking and mastery of combat techniques as players face challenging foes and colossal boss battles.

Furthermore, the game's attention to detail is nothing short of breathtaking. From the stunning landscapes of the Nine Realms to the intricately designed creatures and mythological beings, every aspect of the game is meticulously crafted, showcasing the developers' dedication to delivering a visually stunning and immersive world.

Beyond its technical achievements, "God of War" succeeds in evoking genuine emotions. It's not just a tale of epic battles but a profound exploration of themes like parenthood, sacrifice, and redemption. The emotional depth of the characters and their interactions creates a bond between players and the game world that lingers long after the credits roll.

In conclusion, "God of War" isn't just a game; it's a masterpiece that sets a new standard for storytelling, gameplay mechanics, and visual artistry in the gaming industry. It's a testament to the power of video games as an art form, leaving an indelible mark on anyone fortunate enough to experience its awe-inspiring journey.

I don't care if i get skill issued; this game's combat has a lot of bullshit that it likes to throw at you. 

It feels really inconsistent whether you stagger an enemy with your hits or not. Sometimes, one hit from the blades of chaos is all it takes to stagger a large enemy, other times I hit them with an entire heavy runic attack and they don't flinch. Some monsters are slow, like draugr and hel-walkers or whatever else. Then there's the bullshit enemies.

-Revenants
They constantly teleport around, and usually end their stagger or stun by immediately teleporting away. You can't hit them at first, so you have to command Atreus to shoot them. After that, they are suddenly corporeal and you can hit them for a little while. They have very hard to see projectiles on the ground, and an acid vomit attack that has very little windup. For some reason, they also have a melee hit with their staff that is really quick. It sounds really manageable when there's just one, and it is. When there are multiple? The game has told you to go fuck yourself. At that point, all you can do is hide behind your shield in the corner and throw your axe at them repeatedly. It's not safe to go after one with melee, because you're gonna get hit by one of the others because you're not looking at it. I'm writing this review because I got 4 high level revenants in one room in Ivaldi's workshop, which has a time limit that kills you. You can't afford to play it slow and safe, yet the game keeps spawning enemies that force me to do exactly that. No guides on the internet gave me any conclusive strategy besides "hide behind your shield and throw your axe."

-Wulvers
Werewolves on crack. They have no fucking telegraphs. They're manageable usually, but there's a beefier version that goes into a frenzy mode where nothing can stop it and the bastard flies around like superman with unblockable attacks.

-Tatzelwurms
These little reptilian shitheads like to burrow into the ground and lunge at you with a yellow-circle attack. It's hard enough to deal with a group of *just* tatzelwurms, but throw other enemies into the mix and it's like pushing water uphill. There's also a poisonous variant that is somehow able to hit you for over half your health while staggered from your melee attacks. I don't see this mentioned anywhere and I don't know how to avoid it besides avoiding melee combat entirely.

-The fucking trolls
These ones aren't even hard. They're just, and I can't stress this enough, *FUCKING EVERYWHERE.* Over 75% of this game's boss fights are just recolored trolls. They fixed this in ragnarok, but this isn't a review of that game. This game's boss fights cycle between trolls and ancients, and both of them are really uninteresting. Aside from a few exceptions, of course. And those exceptions were really cool.

-Ancients
Do you like unblockable attacks? Do you like undodgeable attacks? Do you like both at the same time that requires you to hide behind map geometry? Great! Now have the same telegraph for each one of those so the player has to cower behind map geometry the whole fight anyway. And you can't even fight them normally. Outside of spartan rage, the only way to damage these fucks is to throw your axe into their mouth and throw their own shit at them. Really boring and ruins the flow of the combat. Oh, and sometimes there are other enemies to deal with too. Have fun dying because some fuckboy of a draugr came up behind you and gently tapped you, stunning you long enough to get roasted by the ancient's beam.


This game's combat just feels like they designed everything independently and threw them in groups anyway. For how nice this game is to look at and how incredibly well done the characters and story is, I just can't stand the combat. I just wish these things were explained a bit better in a lot of parts, if they have an explanation at all. The "codex" is just Atreus yapping about their lore + one or two obvious things about them.

On low difficulties this game is entirely too easy, on hard difficulties this game is remarkably unfair. There isn't really a sweet spot unless you intentionally neuter your own strength by bringing crappy armor.

I dont really understand the ratings of this game as its basically a broken console port with several issues right from the get go. The immediate pop up of a "playstation survey" was already kinda hillarious but a graphical bug that appeared shortly into the game just made it unplayable. When moving and turning a grey mess of flickering pixels appears around kratos character which is really hurtful to look at. Changing graphics around in pretty much whatever way didnt fix it. As im running hundreds of other games perfectly on my machine i can only blame a lackluster console port here. 

I wanna mention that the graphics in general, even on the highest possible settings, are absolutely outdated and ugly. It looks like a playstation 2 game in some moments.

Its definitely not worth the money and if youre interested in this game you should aim for playing it on console for sure.
