Gorgeous and ugly, light and dark. This is God of War.

Somehow, a game about the God of War who's essentially a mass murderer is... heartwarming? I judge story games by how they make me feel while playing them, and God of War is excellent at emotional play. Sometimes you wanna just take a break because of how depressing it is, and other times you can't stop playing because of how fun and exciting it is. The story is riveting, the characters are surprisingly fun, and the world building is fantastic. The soundtrack is also a highlight.

Stories that are character driven are the best stories, period, and the characters all have emotional depth and great story arcs. Even the characters mentioned only once or twice have stories that you experience in subtle ways.

In terms of gameplay, God of War is super fun! The combat is obviously the highlight, but the world exploration is also really well done. Finding/earning cool new gear, weapons, and enchantments is extremely fun as well. Oh, and I can't forget the side stories, they are super entertaining.

I loved this game. So much so in fact that upon upon completion of the main story I instantly started a New Game + (which, btw, adds tons of cool new gear exclusive to NG+) and 100% completed the game (yes, even taking out every single one of Odin's ravens).

I must say, this is definitely one of the best story games of the past decade, so it's no surprise it's gotten international attention.

Overall, a 9.25/10, would highly recommend.

TL;DR - the highlights of God of War are the combat and the story, but the world exploration, soundtrack, and characters are all fantastic as well. Play this if you're looking for an entertaining yet gritty story with excellent combat mechanics.

everything apart from the actual gameplay is amazing.
The visuals are stunning, the npc character design is so cool and interesting, the depiction of north mythos is breathtaking.
But the actual gameplay consists of mashing buttons and solving mindless repetitive puzzles and walking along a predetermined paths, the side-content is horrendous and rewards nothing but xp and steel which you will be flooded with anyway.
Upgrades do little to change the gameplay loop, unlocking a new attack means nothing when all you do is still click until enemies die.
Gear upgrades are pointless stat boosts and for some reason they insisted on going with a artifact-system to engrave your gear, which does nothing but further slightly boost said pointless stats and overcomlicate things.

Enemy-variety is already low and made even more pointless by the fact that what you do to beat any of them is still just mash buttons, and when the game actually introduces new mechanics to "make it harder" then its one of 3 things...
1. the enemy has a shield and you know need to bash him before you can button mash, which is just another nuisance and does nothing to make the game more interesting og change the way you engage with enemies.
2. the enemy is flying... and now you have to rely on the horrible hit registration of your weapon throws, or wait for BOY to have arrows ready.
3. its a hag and hags are literally the worst part of this game as they can only be damaged after being hit with arrows and this mechanic is so annoying that i would rather deal with hemmoroids.

Combat lacks any kind of soul or real difficulty and changing the difficulty only increases the damage you take and more importantly reduces the damage you deal.
I ended up going with the easiest difficulty simply because i got so tired of bulletsponges and more importantly to avoid grinding pisspoor sidecontent for stat upgrades.
The way you engage with enemies is always just clicking until something dies.
the only two weapons you have are the axe and chaos blades and although their attacks are slightly different both weaposn functionally just require you to click until shit dies.
In the few circumstances it was possible ij just ran across enemies, i wish there was simply a skip button for the combat sections.

Puzzles are designed to be solvable by fucking toddlers and engaging with them feels intellectually insulting, i have nothing more to add.
The game is the most standard triple-a semi-open world gooffest you could imagine.

This is not a game with cutscenes, it is cutscenes with gameplay inbetween to extend playtime.
And unless you really insist on having an anurism i would highly reccomend just watching the cutscenes on youtube, the 50 dollars i spent on this nonsense was not even close to worth it and i didnt even bother with finnishing the game because i simply got so sick of it and instead watched the last parts of the story on online.

God of War (2016) can best be described as a father son road trip and I think this is the area that the game really excels in. Personally, I find the story and ost to be pretty much the parts of the game that I hold no real animosity towards as they serve their purpose superbly and interconnect well with each other. While I do like the story and ost, it really is everything else about this game that I actively dislike. 

Perhaps the problem I have the most issue with is in regards to the gameplay, which I am not really a fan of how the designers went about certain aspects of it. Consider the following, the difficulty setting, before complaints come about about Git Gud are thrown around I believe I should explain myself and my issue with its implementation. I played the game in the hardest available difficulty available to non newgame+ players and my experience with it does not make me excited over the prospect of a higher difficulty because ultimately the way it is achieved leaves a lot to be desired. 

There are two main issues I see with it, first of all, the enemies are given more health and damage, and while one can argue this is how most games handle difficultly there is an inclusion to this that makes the gameplay so much more irritating. As it wouldn't be a real issue if the core mechanics of combat are consistent, however, due to the higher damage/level output of the enemy, they can actually break through your attempts to parry or block with your shield. So effectively you cannot block attacks as getting hit once is Game Over, thus a core aspect of the combat is literally useless to you and that makes the fights so much more boring and slower as instead of beating your opponent through timing your parries or blocking hits, you have to dodge each and every time and slowly whittle down their health... the worst part is that I am not even describing a boss in this scenario, this is literally the first big enemy you face in the overworld and you can consider every one of these opponents that you face in your journey on the same level. 

That being said, the difficulty does eventually ease... when you finally are able to level up through equipment. This in turn means that the difficulty is mainly centralized on the beginning of the game where you are still learning the ropes of the game and remember what I said about blocking and parrying. Due to how the difficulty is balanced, you don't really start to be able to properly time parries till mid-game. God of War is not a difficult game, it is an unfair game at the beginning and only mildly becomes difficult when it comes to fighting the Valkyries several times. While one can argue that I simply needed to lower the difficulty, I would, in turn, argue that nameless mob enemies didn't need their every hit to be unblockable OHKO's and the gameplay outside of parrying actually fun and engaging.

I should also mention how I hate how the level up system is based on the equipment you wear rather than any actual experience but honestly that is a minor gripe all things considered. The only thing it actually affect is how bad the early game if you are playing at a higher difficulty as I said, as well as maybe those privy towards a certain aesthetic choice in attire and want to play a game wearing certain drip. While I understand that concern, as I have said, it is a minor one. 

While not the most original criticism I do feel it is one that is necessary to point out, the overall lack of enemy diversity. This is a similar problem to what I find in Breath of the Wild, as while in a technical sense I guess one can argue that both games have quite the assortment of enemies to fight, due to how the world is designed there is no specialization in the unique locations so you generally fight the same enemies across all the different realms with the only real distinguishing feature being a color palette swap in the most generous of cases. There is one exception, however, but that one exception is a really bad example as in Alfhiem, the main assortment of enemies you usually fight are replaced with.... 1 enemy type that you fight for most of the region. Eventually another variant does get added but its far too late in the experience to matter and even then, those variants still have mostly the same attack patterns. So we left with a general sense of sameness across all the locations in terms of enemy variety.

This problem in turn starts to affect the bosses as for the most part, the majority of bosses in this game are simply beefed up enemies that you can fight in the world while exploring. Not only that but some of the bosses that you do not face while exploring are repeatable, I am, of course, talking about the Valkyries as while I do admit they are fun to fight against... the first time, you can choose to fight multiple variants of these bosses should you explore and find them. There are minor differences in their movesets but the point is you still have to fight several of them and those minor differences in movesets do not adequately justify the amount of times you do.
 
While a lot of the enemies are indeed rehashes, there is still also the issue with the bosses that are unique as they are for the most a major departure of the previous GOW titles in terms of boss design. For reference, I personally like the Boss fights against Hermes and Cronos in GOW 3, because functionally they play out more like a stage than an actual fight, you have to reach a certain point in the level and complete a couple of objectives to defeat the boss so to speak. They work almost like puzzles and this was a large part of the appeal in those games, the puzzle and the scale of enemies. Sadly, I feel this was mostly lost in the new games. For example, the only real big enemy that you fight in the game would be the Dragon. In previous games, you would've certainly been fighting on its back while it was moving and using those lightning crystals to start blowing apart each limb individually until the climactic finish, which I will admit the finisher in this game was rather old GOW in its brutality, but the point remains that the fight played out very differently. Instead you are on a circular arena and hitting the limbs of the dragon while it is just standing there for the most part. It is not cinematic and doesn't reach anywhere close to the scale as the previous games. Despite that, I would say that was the highlight of the game in terms of bosses as the other fights are either buffed enemies or humanoid ones such as Baldor or Magni and Modi. Baldor, while a great villain, I wish the final fight itself took even more lessons from the final Zeus fight. [spoiler] Such the Stone Giant actually being part of the fight instead of just a background detail like how you actually had to destroy Gaia 's heart while fighting Zeus as well as using her to heal. [/spoiler] So while the boss fights are fun, most are repetitive and the actual good ones don't quite have the same scale as the old games, which I think is a travesty.
 
While I do ultimately recommend this game, I do so reluctantly as I have already noted in explicit detail, there is a lot of things that I actually dislike about this game and not a lot that I view positively. This is also included in the fact that I do not like the direction the sequel took the series due to it not really solving the majority of the issues I had with game and in some cases only serve to exasperate some of the deeper flaws as well as just poor design choices overall but enough about the sequel. The point is this game is a relatively mixed bag for me and the more I think about it, the less positive of an impression I am left with, however, even after all these years I am still left recommending this game mostly do to its coherent narrative and story about a father teaching his BOY about being a moral and upstanding person.

[h1]Epic Norse Odyssey - God of War on PC [/h1]

[b]Review:[/b]
God of War's arrival on PC brings Kratos' epic Norse journey to a whole new audience, and it doesn't disappoint. This legendary action-adventure title, originally a PlayStation exclusive, shines on the PC platform, delivering a visually stunning and emotionally gripping experience.

[b]Graphics & Performance:[/b]
The transition to PC has done wonders for God of War's visuals. The game looks breathtaking, with detailed character models, rich environments, and smooth, responsive controls. The option for higher resolutions and frame rates on PC enhances the overall cinematic feel.

[b]Story & Characters:[/b]
God of War's narrative is a triumph, seamlessly blending Norse mythology with a deeply emotional father-son story. Kratos and Atreus' journey is both grand and intimate, with strong character development and engaging storytelling that keeps you invested from start to finish.

[b]Combat System:[/b]
The combat system is nothing short of spectacular. Kratos' Leviathan Axe feels weighty and powerful, and the addition of Atreus as a combat companion adds strategic depth. Each encounter is a thrilling ballet of violence and strategy.

[b]PC Optimization:[/b]
Santa Monica Studio has done an excellent job optimizing the game for PC. The settings menu offers a range of options to tailor the experience to your hardware, ensuring smooth performance across a variety of systems.

[b]Conclusion:[/b]
God of War's PC adaptation is a triumph, bringing an already exceptional game to new heights. From its stunning visuals and emotional narrative to the visceral combat, this version cements God of War as a must-play for PC gamers seeking a truly epic and immersive experience.

You don't need me to tell you that this is an amazing game worth your time. 
What I will tell you is a few flaws that by no means put this below a great experience. 

The skill tree is fine, but the equipment, crafting and levelling system all seems like it's tacked on because they wanted an open world game and needed to put something in it aside from the story. 

Lastly, the combat is fine but not special. This would be fine except most of the gameplay is combat. This came to a head during the valkyrie fight in muspelheim where on top of a lot of valkyrie attacks being very fast/wide requiring perfect dodging and timing, there is an unblockable AOE attack that you can use the quick turn (apparently) to negate the damage if you don't face the attack. This is a) the first time I've actually used this mechanic throughout my 25 hour playthrough and b) not consistent.

[h1] An epic aventure in the company of the Gods! [/h1] 

[b] Overall [/b] : 9/10

God of War is a MUST HAVE for any fan of action adventure game. An epic story, beautiful graphics, great gameplay, great soundtrack, all the ingredients for one of the best game on PC and a really nice port from Playstation!.

[b] Gameplay [/b] : 9/10

The game combines exploration phase and combat phase. You have basically an semi-open world setting, as the map is divided into zones that you can explore, but within those zones, it's mostly corridor base. The exploration will allow you to find artifacts, weapons and armors that will help you grow in your journey. The combat phase is great and very dynamic. Lots of possible combos, with 2 different weapons. 

[b] Graphics [/b] : 10/10

Just magnificent. If you cam experience it in 4K HDR, that will blow your eyes. Sharp textures, great FX, beautiful lightings.

[b] Story [/b] : 9/10

If you know the God of War trilogy, this one basically follows the same character but in a different setting and much later after the events of the first 3. Having playing the trilogy helps but is definetely not a requirement.
The story is rather long and will take you across various realms. Great characters will unfold and I found the pacing very good.

[b] Achievements [/b] : 5/10

For the hunters out there, the game requires a bit of grind, and now comes THE advice. DO NOT play for your 100% attempt, on Give me God Of War difficulty (the highest). That was my mistake and it was very painful. As there is no difficulty achievement, and the highest tier is extremely punishing. You have been warmed. Otherwise, quite straightforward, but 2 achievements essentially will be annoying, requiring quite a grind to get them. Overall, it was a fun 100% thanks to the game quality.

God of war 4 is a game that I have been waiting to come to PC for a while. And when it finally made its debut on steam I knew I had to get it. This game is a great game, although ive noticed its age and how it falls short. Firstly, this game has an incredible story, although the plot is very simple, the characters are three dimensional and complex. Every character feels real and grounded, which helps the player connect with and understand the intricacies of each properly. The story is easily this game's best feature. Secondly, the combat and progression in this game feels great. I loved the weight of my attacks and the satisfaction of upgrading my equipment and abilities. I played through on the second hardest difficulty, and I am looking to play again on the hardest. The gameplay is a definite win from me, even if it copied fromsoft's homework it still remains fun. Lastly, unfortunately I noticed some lagspikes and frame drops on my computer whilst playing even at the lowest settings. This type of performance is not normal for a computer such as mine, which while not top of the line still holds its own in titles such as cyberpunk and elden ring or starfield. Even so, I found the graphics to not be as I remember them on release years ago, textures were blurry even on high settings and grass and hair particularly ruined the illusion. But I digress, the game is not brand new and still manages to be beautiful as a whole. Nitpicks aside, this game is absolutely worth a buy and is a must-have for any gamer who craves the singleplayer RPG's of old.

I was legitimately surprised when Sony dropped this title on PC. After Horizon Zero Dawn released a while back I was optimistic that this game would release. Lo and behold, the bastards did it. And not only is this a great entry from one of my all-time favorite Playstation franchises, it's a damn well-optimized port as well-- with ultra-wide support, DLSS, and all the bells and whistles a good PC game would usually ship with.

As for the game itself, it's pretty fantastic. The combat is weighty and chock-full of impact. Every swing you land with the Leviathan axe has a palpable meatiness to it. Plus throwing the axe and having it come back to you in time for you to continue chopping away at foes just feels incredible.

Story-wise the game is also strong. In this entry Kratos fathers another child: a young, naive boy named Atreus, who knows very little of Kratos' cold, harsh temper. While it *is* a reboot in the sense that the franchise is bringing back Kratos and his familiar roots, practically all of the previous entries of the game aren't entirely forgotten-- in fact the consequences of Kratos' actions from those games take a surprisingly large part of the game's narrative here, and it directly affects his relationship with Atreus. I also like how much of these elements are delivered to the player, as it both informs newcomers to the franchise and tosses a bone to longtime fans (like me!)

There are a couple of downsides to this game that I wasn't entirely pleased about. The biggest issue was this game's glaring lack of boss variety. Sure there were some great highlights such as the fight with the Stranger in the beginning of the game, or the huge battle with Hraezlyr in the mountain, but It seems that a notable half of the game's bosses were just the same two-story, pillar-lugging troll that you've definitely seen from the E3 presentation back in 2016.
Additionally I really didn't find myself liking the PC controls as much as I thought I would be with this port. As I struggled to fidget with the controls during the first fight it was really apparent how much this game was designed to be played with controllers in mind. Actions like heavy and light attacks, paired with throwing and recalling the Leviathan axe feels awkward  with a mouse and keyboard. If you're just jumping into this game I definitely recommend that you grab a controller for this one.

Despite all the setbacks, though, I still believe this is a very good game, and definitely something to consider if you're looking for a nice single-player game to kick back to. Sony made a real good decision bringing all of these exclusive titles to PC and I definitely look forward to seeing more titles from them coming to this platform. Here's to hoping Ragnarok releases very soon!

I've thought long and hard about why I ultimately cannot recommend this. And before I give my reasons, one thing has to be made clear: We are at an age where decent (even good) games are being released ALL THE TIME. And games are also getting more and more expensive because of inflation. So the bar for what I can recommend must also be raised if I have to be absolutely honest.

So bearing this in mind, here is why I don't think this game is worth playing.

(1) The story: It's just not enough for a story to be thought as good simply because it resembles a movie. The story here is...just alright? Fine? Good even at places. But what started off super promising ultimately reduces to a series of fetch quests where you're constantly told that you need to get this in order to go there and in order to go there you need to do this favour for that person etc. etc. Granted, big RPGs do this all the time (even the much-revered Witcher 3 does it), but this game relies on this particular trope as a plot device so freaking often that it just gets inane and ridiculous really fast. The story, immersive at first, ultimately reminds you constantly that you are experiencing a "video game story" - and no amount of cinematic camerawork can salvage that. What's more, a lot of the character-building is done through dialogue with Atreus while you're roaming the world so if you don't 100% the game you literally don't get a lot of the emotional pay-off and I find this design choice ultimately to the detriment of the story. While the voice actors all did a phenomenal job, I find Atreus' anachronistic mannerisms grating at times as he almost talks like a Tik-tok kid from the 2020s, not exactly appropriate for the time period if I may say so.

(2) The gameplay is clunky: The combat is clearly inspired by the Souls formula except you'll be battling with the camera half the time because they'd rather it be cinematic than actually fun to use. And yes, while you can quick turn-around by clicking on the D-pad it's still annoying when you're fighting high-level enemies and you necessarily have your attention taken away by wrestling with the camera. You can certainly frame it as a skill issue because one can certainly master fighting and fighting with a terrible camera, doesn't mean it's a skill I'd like to - as a gamer - master though. For the hassle it caused me I just don't think mastery of this particular system would quite justify the effort it'd take to "git gud". There's also a Shadow of Mordor-esque/Destiny-inspired loot system which I find to be just plain obnoxious. You get 70% of the time useless items but it's all scattered around the map with a Ubisoft-checklist to pad out the game's length and "encourage exploration". Granted, there is a lot to see, and the details they put into the world is amazing. I still think the loot system is overwhelming and doesn't contribute to the combat as much as it contributes to the gamer's headache in trying to wrap their head around all the upgrades, runes, charms that you can equip.

(3) Terrible level-designs: Apart from one set-piece that I don't want to spoil mid-game, you mostly just traverse through tight, linear, and narrow corridors populated by generic enemies that you will default back to the same three strategies you use whenever you fight them (offensive, evasive, range-mainly). I think judging from the lukewarm reviews of Ragnarok (this game's sequel I haven't played) people are finally starting to see through the bs of the design philosophy of "cinematic" games where loading screens happen alongside boring walking/climbing sections where you push your joystick in one direction and sit back for exposition dumps. The enemy finishers are so few that they get repetitive really fast. The puzzles and the deathtraps also overstate their welcome very quickly. It's like they built these systems for the game and now everything has to revolve around them which means the devs can only be so creative about the types of enemy encounters and puzzle varieties. The world they've built here is not the sort of world that lends itself well to an open-world formula, and while this isn't an open-world game, it does open up gradually as you progress. But unlike Arkham Asylum for instance where you can go anywhere that's unlocked at any time of the story and use your new gadgets to access previously inaccessible areas, GoW (2018) will lock you out of areas because you're at a point in the story where it makes no sense for you to go to those regions. This is so even after unlocking diegetic fast-travel in game! At this point why not design a truly linear, unique experience with variegated levels and enemy encounters, instead of this open-world-Metroidvania-hybrid game where you don't get the joys of exploratory freedom when playing something like The Red Dead Redemption, and yet you don't get the kind of depth to level design like the levels in Dishonored either?

(4) Bizarre and outright bad game design choices: The Valkyries are not hard because they have complicated movesets. They are hard because they are damage sponges and the camera control is so awkward that you have the odds stacked against you by having to deal with the same 2 movesets for 15 minutes while your camera will over time almost certainly screw you over. You don't feel good or a sense of accomplishment by finishing these bosses off, you just get pissed off and frustrated and you try again and again until luck would have it that you beat one of them, and then you realise there're 8 more to fight. The moves that you get from investing in skills also rarely make a difference unless you're intrinsically motivated to vary your combat style just to look cooler while playing. I think it comes down to the laziness of enemy placement where if your gear is good enough you can pretty much spam the same basic combo and get by just fine, without ever having to use any of the new moves you learn. This is such a shame because that means most people will probably not be motivated to use the moves they unlock and they'd end up forgetting about most of them anyway even after finishing the game. This is different from a game like Sekiro where you literally make moves you learn your own by fully grasping what their situational uses are and so it feels much much better when you pull these off. Here you just unlock moves because...you do? And then you proceed to use the same basic-ass combos until you realise you're the source of your own misery ("You're not playing the game cinematically enough") and YOU are ultimately responsible for changing things up because the game couldn't be bothered to force you to by featuring more creative levels. There's also the (especially towards the end) extremely predictable "gauntlet of three" where you get to an area, have your progress artificially impeded by some event while the game throws three waves of enemies at you. Sometimes this gets nested into a broader gauntlet of three where the event will have to play out three times so there will be a total of 9 waves. Riveting level design I know.

I know I could come off as harsh and I realise this is a game beloved by many. And yes the production value is high, the voice-acting is gold standard, and the music and sound design is excellent. Playing the game with a Dual-shock PS5 controller can be quite immersive too. If you played this and loved it there's nothing I've said that you don't already know and disagree with. This review is for people who've played a lot of games, don't really care a lot about graphics/how cinematic a story is so long as it's good, and people who just don't have all the money in the world to buy every game that looks mildly interesting. I think if you're after a story-rich game with fun combat this game is just too mid to get a recommendation:

It's got a story, just not a very rich one; and it's got a serviceable combat, but it's just not very fun to play.

In theory this is a very flawed game. Atreus's character is annoying and doesn't make a lot of sense. Quite a few bosses are recycled. The platforming is completely fake so that people who are even worse at video games than me can still beat it, and the camera can sometimes get you into trouble. But god damn it, the presentation, the weighty, crunch combat, the environments, the graphics, the music the characters, it all just comes together into something so epic you probably won't care about all the stuff wrong with it. Games do not need to be perfect to be great and this game is proof.

Steam Deck review! I gave this game a shot after missing out on all previous games before it, because PlayStation exclusivity. I will say as someone come from zero prior experience, the game does a fine job of introducing relevant backstory elements in a way that isn't confusing, but may leave you wondering whats going on.

Did I mention steam deck? Yes I did! This game works fairly well after scaling back a few settings. I think the steam deck has trouble with atmospheric stuff like clouds. When you bring those down and increase the quality of everything else, it runs really well. My only issue with it is that when it does crash you have to hard reboot the deck to get out of the crash.

Would recommend to anyone that wants a glimpse into the God of War storyline that hasn't experienced it before.

Overrated. Cumbersome combat with a way-too-close camera that isn't adjustable, yet tons of enemy reliance on flanking offscreen. It just makes the fights annoying. The animations and visuals are great, but combat lacks the somewhat tactical feel of earlier GOW games. Definitely too much faffing about with the boy, too much story. Some people love games that are just interactive movies, but I prefer the focus to be on gameplay. Everything in this game feels scripted and stiff. Kratos, who should feel tanky and powerful, is a wimp who can only take 2-3 hits before dying. The early hours of the game are a scripted slog and play control feels like molasses compared to other high-end ARPGs I've played. Environments look great, but are relatively boring linear corridors (with the occasional obligatory boring puzzle / loop-around paths) with little in them that is interactive or destructable. 

To me, despite the high production value, this is a step in the wrong direction for the franchise.

The first and most striking aspect of "God of War" is its narrative depth. The game follows Kratos, the iconic Spartan warrior, now navigating the harsh landscapes of Norse mythology with his son, Atreus. The storytelling is masterfully executed, revealing layers of Kratos' character and exploring themes of fatherhood, loss, and redemption. The emotional resonance of the narrative is unparalleled, drawing players into a world where gods, monsters, and mortals collide in a tragic yet beautiful dance.

The visual and artistic prowess of "God of War" is nothing short of awe-inspiring. The game's environments are richly detailed, from the towering peaks of Midgard to the dark realms of Helheim. The character designs, especially Kratos and Atreus, are meticulously crafted, conveying a range of emotions that add depth to the storytelling. The use of a single, continuous camera shot throughout much of the game creates a sense of immersion rarely seen in the medium.

The combat system is a symphony of brutality and finesse. Kratos' Leviathan Axe becomes an extension of the player's will, offering a satisfying blend of strategic attacks and visceral executions. The addition of Atreus as a combat ally introduces a layer of strategy, providing ranged support and enabling dynamic combo possibilities. The upgrade system allows for meaningful progression, ensuring that battles remain challenging and rewarding.

Exploration in "God of War" is a joy in itself. The world is interconnected, filled with hidden chambers, puzzles, and lore-rich artifacts. Each area tells a story, and the game encourages players to delve into the rich tapestry of Norse mythology through a series of optional quests and collectibles.

The musical score, composed by Bear McCreary, complements the grandeur of the game. From the haunting chants to the powerful orchestral pieces, the soundtrack enhances the emotional impact of key moments, further immersing players in the epic journey.

"God of War" is not just a game; it's an interactive masterpiece that transcends the boundaries of the medium. Its meticulous attention to detail, gripping narrative, and innovative gameplay make it a benchmark for the potential of storytelling in video games. Even years after its release, "God of War" remains a shining example of what can be achieved when creativity, technology, and narrative prowess converge. It's a timeless experience that will be remembered as one of the industry's finest achievements.

This game is the package deal when it comes to story-driven games. 

It has a beautiful world packed with entertaining characters that you will love. Kratos isn't the same god he was in the original trilogy, and his character change is in line with his shaky but endearing relationship with his son, Atreus.

The world building was excellent, the musical score and the visuals are great considering it is a 5 year old game now. 

A classic tale of a journey that stems from a seemingly simple request that leads into exciting fights with gods and getting murdered by strange creatures you pull out of dimensional holes.

The standard of games has been shaky the last few years, but games like this make me excited to play games again.

I hate the fact that every fight has to be (+2) mobs or more. You can't use your attacks, because you never have time to finish the attack animation. Mobs that get hit once will randomly level up and get health back (unless interrupted). There should be an option to change the fucking camera view distance when in combat.  You have no idea, what is going on with mobs 0.5 meter to the left or right of you. All you get is a vague arrow, pointing that a mob is in that direction. I'm playing on the hardest difficulty, and the mobs have too much health. 1 hit deals 1/20 of 1 mobs health, if they are higher level (+3). I can dodge a mob 20 times and weave in attacks, but it's repetitive. 

I do enjoy God of War. It's a passion project for sure. I'll die 1000 times to beat this game, I don't care.

I loved almost everything about this game.  First off, unskippable cutscenes in New Game+ is always a strike against any game.  It's unacceptable considering how easy it would be to implement.  
I also have concerns about balancing of the bosses in this game, specifically that in comparison to optional bosses, the story bosses often feel weak, especially in NG+.  Better level scaling or just some balance tweaking on bosses like Baldur and Magni/Modii would make them a lot more engaging.
The combat is really fun but admittedly it's completely different from the originals of the series.  Personally, after playing all but one of the original 7 games, I'm completely fine with a bottom-up rework of the combat.  Everything you can do in this game feels satisfying and the writing is actually solid.  Voice acting is stellar and is deserving of the awards it's gotten / been nominated for.  
I think the developers decided the game either had to reinvent itself or die.  I think it's safe to say they successfully reinvented one of my favorite franchises, somehow, into one of my favorite games I've played.

Overall the game is an interesting well written story.  I'm over 25 hours into play.  My main dislike with the game is that at least 5 hours of that is half play/half cutscenes where you have to sit and hold the controller forward and watch your character walk very slowly.  There is very little dialog to keep you interested and they drag on way too long.  Then there are actual cutscenes like riding very slowly in a boat for 20 minutes or watching the characters talk and having to press a button every 5 minutes to keep the scene moving.  Of course there are also cutscenes travelling in elevators that go on for way too long.  These things completely take me out of the game and can be extremely frustrating because the amount of time I have to play is limited.

Update:  Finished the game.  The story was incredibly well written, but the game is just not well designed.  The combat is clunky and over-complicated.  The map is useless for navigation.  The fast travel even forces you to run long distances instead of just taking you from one point to the next.  There are multiple open door/chest mechanics that require you to get a certain item before you can open them, but these chests and doors are in even the very first area forcing backtracking for no real reason.  Of the 9 realms, 4 don't unlock until after you beat the game.  Two of those don't unlock unless you start a new game plus.  There is nothing interesting in them.  Just areas to grind for more armor after you've already finished the game.  A+ for the writers.  F- for the developers.

The story is one of the best told by the medium, and it will continue to live in my mind rent-free. Please give this game a try. This was honestly one of the most enjoyable games that I've played in a while. Though my hours say 3.2 I've played at least 200+ hours of 'offline' play due to the deck not counting hours. 

For people who are considering playing this on the deck the experience what not too bad I had around 40 fps on mid/low settings but it still felt nice and wasn't to choppy. 

As for the gameplay, the story progressed very nicely guiding you through the story in a thoughtful way. When it comes to upgrading or improving skills I wish some of the aspects were explained a little bit more like where I can find items to upgrade or craft improved armor. The combat mechanics were really smooth on deck I would definitely recommend configuring the back paddles to some of your keys or creating some quick attack binds to better the flow of combat. 

But as a person who generally plays FPS and shooters, this was definitely one for the books and it definitely lived up to the hype that has been spewed everywhere.

I only ever owned PS2, so I never played God of War, but heard great reviews. Not really knowing much about it, I started with reviews (honest ones) and then watched a trailer...decided, to hell with it and gave it a chance. WOW! I am SOOO glad I did. I honestly had to look up how to get through the first gate on youtube (probably because I skimmed and didnt read fully - which is HIGHLY encouraged). Once I got the hang of it, gameplay is GREAT. The story is good so far, I'm upgrading weapons now that I've ventured down that path some more and I love the (unexpected) puzzles you have to solve in order to get into some chests. Dont always go "straight" down the path, look around and you'll find a ton of collectibles and points to upgrade your axe and bow. Would definitely recommend this game to anyone who likes 3rd person battle games (its almost like Tomb Raider, but different lol), who likes puzzling solving - its not necessary, but its fun! and someone who likes fantasy games....if you can get it on sale for $30 like I did, its worth it...even though it came out years ago on playstation and only in 2022 did it come to steam, I'd still pay the $30 for it.

This game is weird...

In theory it's amazing and has all of the necessary ingredients for a great title...
On the other hand it just feels so incredibly formulaic and constrained...

Even though I very much enjoy action fighting games in hubs this one just felt like it was playing it safe too much...

Yes: there are amazing moments in it and it can get quite emotional at times - but in between there is an endless ocean of mediocrity in my eyes...

The majority of people seem to love the game and maybe that very hype and expectations of something truly extraordinary killed a solid game for me...

Still: I finished it, sometimes forcing myself to go on and increasingly ignoring side-stuff...

Maybe if you go in with reduced expectations you can have a great time...
I wish you more success than what I had...

"God of War" is a visual masterpiece. The game's graphics are stunning, with breathtaking landscapes, meticulously detailed character models, and fluid animations that bring the world of Norse mythology to life. The transition from cutscenes to gameplay is seamless, creating an immersive cinematic experience. The audio design is equally impressive, with an epic score that enhances the emotional depth of the story. The voice acting, particularly by Christopher Judge as Kratos, adds a powerful layer of authenticity and gravitas to the characters.

TLDR - so-so game on super sale

Negatives:
- I'm the God of War and they have me stuck by tiny ledges and stupid mini games. These would be tolerable if they were one-offs but they happen all the fucking time. 
- Scaling ledges, climbing, etc. over and over is tedious and boring. I'm the god of war. Pick up my boy and jump. 
- Enemies are hit sponges. 
- Too much random shit to pick up. Am I saving up for a duvet cover at the market? 
- Dialogue is very inconsistent. One second someone will say something cruel and the next second kind.
- You have to repetitively initiate conversations just to get through all of the disjointed dialogue. 
- Most upgrades are non-engaging and just increases the pre-existing value. Boring.
- You can't skip dialogue or cut scenes.

Positives: 
- You feel powerful at times
- Looks nice most of the time, but only at maxed out settings and DLSS/FSR off. Yes, OFF

The new RPG elements of this game compared to its predecessors make this feel brand new. It really does feel like a new game franchise with some familiar faces. I highly recommend for anyone who loved previous GOW titles to give this jump into modern graphics and game systems like talent trees and upgrading armor and weapons with Kratos and "boy" a shot.

So, just like whenever this released back on PS4, this game is still an absolute masterpiece. Sony revitalized the GoW franchise like very few have ever done their own titles. The graphics are nearly photorealistic at times. The combat is fluid, and if you're on the right difficulty setting, fluid and brutal. The story is the best that has been attached to Kratos yet where you'll be shocked, angered, laughing, and so much more. Honestly, at this point, I'm just wondering why you're still reading my review and not already playing it. Easy 10/10.

God of War is one of the best story games I've played. Kratos' emotional depth sets the standard for strong and dynamic protagonists. Combat starts off fairly simple, but unlocking various abilities (and eventually another weapon) provides a slow approach to advanced combat, which is more than welcome. The Valkyrie fights are a must play, in my humble opinion.  The realms in God of War are diverse, however some are more fleshed out than others. Muspelheim, for example, is boiled down to combat challenges that feel more repetitive than necessary. This realm is optional, however, and allow players to continue unlocking enchantments and armor if they are hungry for more. The world progression involves simple puzzles using the axe that keeps progression simple but makes you think at times. The lore and storytelling is abundant but not overwhelming, consisting of learning lore through shrines and conversations with Mimir. 9/10 from me. Waiting on Ragnarok

Both games are absolute masterpieces that you should absolutely play

grew up with mostly xbox consoles as a kid so was never able to play the god of war series even though it looked really cool and i wanted to. i now use pc so after reading up on the lore of kratos up until this point, i bought this game and all i have to say is i wish i couldve experienced the story from the start because i love pretty much everything about it and the plot is fantastic. not a big fan of the puzzles, they often seem like morbid IQ tests but i usually dont like puzzles in video games so thats just me. the combat mechanics could use the littlest bit of polishing but overall pretty smooth and super fun to learn and quite frankly badass. if you like games like the arkham series then youll love the puzzles and combat, and if youre interested at all in greek and norse mythology youll be glued to the screen for every cut scene. if youre like me and never tried these games before and are thinking about giving this one a go id suggest getting on youtube and learning about the story and then immediately buying this game. like most games its slow to start but as you get more weapons and abilities youll soon realize why they were and are so popular. overall id give it a solid 8.5/10 not much to hate about this game. get it.

Going to be bias here seeing as God of War is my favorite single player series and I haven't missed a beat. The game is story rich. The ties back to the previous titles does not overshadow this one. Lore that's worth reading and plays along with the game. I personally liked the combat which is a breath of fresh air for the new format. Performed excellent for me with about 3 things happening through out my 50 hours of game play.

I don't have much on the downsides of the game for me. The blinding white light when getting hit hard, sometimes tedious travel methods, and an uneven amount of enemies ability to run away from you mid fight. Other than that, the game was amazing. Yeah

This is one of the rare games I could recommend to everyone who loves great combat in gaming. You always feel like you're innovating, adding onto your combat skills way more than some of my other favourite games like the dark souls franchise. It's so beautiful and intricate, the story is very very good and it's worth sinking your time into. Sure, this game has many cutscenes which might bore people at first(can't say i haven't felt the same about it at some points), and sure the game might have its fair share of flaws(sometimes it does suffer from enemy spam, and the balancing is a bit rough sometimes if you go do optional stuff before you finish the game). But this game compels you to do way less exploring before finishing the main content first where its honestly way more balanced than even dark souls 3, which I found adequately balanced throughout. 

One of my only complaints really is that it gives dwarf favours way earlier than you can actually finish them(I was 80% done and the first favour for sindri still had enemies that could one-shot me).

My advice for the difficulty is to pick "give me a balanced experience". Every difficulty is, as far as I saw, balanced well. However "give me a story" is more balanced as an accessibility difficulty setting with how slowed the enemies are, your vs their damage output and reaction time windows. For the average able-bodied person with time to spare(story is approximately 25-30 hour long) this difficulty setting will get you blazing through the enemies and not really requiring you to learn the combat system anymore than the basics. That's not to say the balanced experience option will teach you to the core how the system works but you will definitely feel badass learning all the combos, moves, advantages and disadvantages of enemies and you will feel satisfied and a powerful menace to the inhabitants of the realms.

In short, "play" the game on youtube. Totally overrated. It's like dry dung - people suggest you to chew on it a little more to get the taste and it will "bloom". But you know it's enough to sniff it a little to understand what's coming.

In a little more detail.
Click enemy to death. Everything is so dragged, long "realistic" animations. Terribly cheesy unispiring combat (basic punch, strong punch, block, roll and throw/return axe + Spartan rage). Maybe studio made this in favor of realism, I don't know. If so it was a bad choice.
There's also a horribly boring intro and an autistic son.
No desire to play. Going after a deer with my son - alrighty. But when a tattooed crackhead came to my house asking questions and i had to beat him three times, I dropped the game.
I remembered those dark days of gaming, when the 7th generation consoles (PS3 and X360) came out - a lot of similar cheesy artificially dragged out games came out then. Maybe the plot is somewhat interesting, but the presentation of gameplay and mechanics made in an extremely bad tone (example from the subj: for some reason in the introduction you have to click to cut down a birch tree...), this was infuriating 15 years ago. And now it's completely disgraceful to do so. To be honest, the first half hour of the game can simply be replaced by a cutscene. And teach the mechanics in a slightly more interactive way than it is.
=========================
Если коротко, то пройдите игру на ютубе. Абсолютно переоценена. Как засохшая гавеха - люди предлагают разжевать ее вдумчиво и тогда пойдет вкус и игра раскроется. Но ты знаешь, что такую игру достаточно слегка нюхнуть, чтобы понять, что к чему.

Если чуть поподробнее.
Закликай врага досмерти. Тягомотина. Жутко убогая боевка (основной удар, сильный удар, блок, перекат и кинуть/вернуть топор + спартанская ярость). Может быть в угоду реализма, не знаю. Но зря так.
Еще жутко муторное вступление и сын-аутист.
Из-за всего этого играть нет желания. Поход за оленем с сыном я еще осилил. Но вот когда татуированный зек пришел ко мне домой с какими-то вопросами и пришлось три раза его бить, я закрыл игру.
Вспомнились темные времена гейминга, когда вышли консоли 7 поколения (PS3 и X360), - тогда вышло много подобных убогих игр. Может сюжет там и сколько-то интересный, но подача геймплея и механик сделана в крайне дурном тоне (пример из сабжа: зачем-то во вступлении надо покликать, чтобы срубить березу), который бесил 15 лет назад. А сейчас так делать совсем позорно. Если честно, то первые полчаса игры можно просто заменить катсценой. А обучить механикам чуть более интерактивным путем, чем есть.

Before playing this game, my knowledge and interest in the God of War series was very limited. Aside from gaming on PC, I have only ever played video games on the Xbox family of consoles. As a result, I never bothered paying attention or getting interested in this franchise as it has  always been a PlayStation exclusive. However, when I found out this game was coming to PC, I made the decision to purchase it and play it due to it being considered one of the best console exclusives of the last generation. 

I was not disappointed. This game is without a doubt one of the best action-adventure games I have ever played. I will spare you the details of describing why this game is good mechanically visually as I cannot do it justice. Rest assured, this game is not buggy, provides enough of a challenge to keep you engaged and entertained, has interesting lore, impeccable dialogue, and is visually pretty. 

But what I find most interesting about this game is the story, Sure, on the surface, it is exciting as it is basically the story of a reformed god of war coming out of retirement for another important mission. And now he has a kid! But deep down, this story is much simpler but more interesting. Looking past the Norse mythology and the established lore of Kratos, this is a story of a father and son who must learn from each other. Kratos, a tough father with a dark past, has to learn how to tell his son about who he is while also protecting him from the world around him. Atreus, a boy who wishes to be accepted by his father but chafes under his domineering nature, must learn about his complicated lineage and reconcile with the fact that his father's strict, authoritarian parenting-style is necessary to prepare him for the world he will inhabit. Together, they learn about one another and from one another in way that is both interesting and entertaining to the player.

Along with stellar gameplay, stunning visuals, and an interesting supporting cast, particularly the exploration of the relationship between an important side character and the main antagonist that provides a nice literary foil, this game is great. I would strongly recommend anybody that likes third-party action adventure to play this game.

For a game with a universally praised narrative, I expected much more. The characters, or should I say caricatures, are so predictable and frustrating: troubled father who refuses to open up to his son, irritated son who seeks father's affection... that's about it (until dad realises he should be kind to his kid). The son also went through a really stupid character arc that felt entirely inauthentic to his personality, then reversed back like it never happened. I did enjoy the combat, but the story just missed the mark.

Altogether, great combat mechanics from "old" Kratos (one flaw is that the boy needs improvement in the upcoming Ragnarok game) & immersive experience in a godlike realm followed with countless secrets waiting to be uncovered. If ur a GoW veteran like me, playing from the beginning of the franchise on the old-school PSP console (nostalgia activated), this title is a must try!

I 100%ed God of War. This game is an absolute masterpiece to the point where I've dedicated 67.5 hours to it as I type this, and I'm not nearly done replaying it.
The relationships are complex, realistic, and compelling, the mythology is captivating and made me want to learn more about Norse mythology and culture, the gameplay is fun and easy to switch up, and despite how I'm not that good at remembering combos and extra attacks, I got through it just fine and enjoyed every second (even Niflheim). I'm replaying it through the New Game+ mechanic and I was shocked that there is extra content to continue leveling up my gear, which I did not expect. This and its sequel are incredible, riveting material that is absolutely worth the hours I put into it and deserves the love it receives, if not more. Santa Monica Studio, Christopher Judge, Sunny Suljic, Jeremy Davies, Danielle Bisutti, Alastair Duncan... I could go on and on naming these incredible actors and couldn't even begin to scratch the surface of talent among cast, crew, and creators. Thank you for this gorgeous game that has given us so much joy and excitement. There aren't enough words.

TL;DR: This game is amazing, play it. 9.5/10

(SPOILERS AHEAD)
So I slept on this game hard and didn't play it until only a few weeks ago. My reasons for this that I never owned a PS4 and I had heard that this game was essentially an interactive movie so I put it on the backburner until it felt like the right time to play it. I greatly regret not playing this game sooner because holy crap, this game is amazing and I'll explain why.

Story:
So, GoW 4 takes place in a whole new mythology, that being Norse. Kratos made a new family in Midgard after the events of GoW 3 and sought to have a quiet, peaceful life until his wife passed away. Her final wish was to have her ashes spread from the highest point in all of the nine realms. So, Kratos and his son embark on a journey to do just that, but face many trials along the way.

This story is awesome. It shows us a side of Kratos that we really haven't seen before, that being his quiet and compassionate side. He comes to grip with the reality that the new life he had built is crumbling away and he's pretty much powerless. He also is figuring out how to be a better father to Atreus and you can see that he does love his son, but he's terrified to make mistakes so he comes off as cold and distant. This portrayal of Kratos is emotional and realistic, and I love it. This story will make you feel like a badass as well as making you feel like you grew alongside these characters.

Gameplay/Combat:
This combat is just fun as hell. It makes you feel like a complete badass as you get unbelievably strong and take down enemies effortlessly that were previously major trials. It's also reminiscent of FromSoft, but nowhere near as difficult so if you enjoy that kind of gameplay, there's something here for you.

Completionist Difficulty:
This is a pretty easy game to get all of the achievements in as it only took me 60 hours to do so. If you take your time and explore, you'll 100% this game in no time.

Nitpicks:
There's too many ravens to shoot down and Niflheim is annoying to be in.

When this game was out, it was hailed like the Messiah of video games (like Baldur's gate or Elden Ring is hailed right now). And in a sense it was. A game with great combat, systems with depth that served the game perfectly, no loading screens, no micro-transactions, no lootboxes, no paid DLC, no monetization, no "will fix it later". Just an incredible game with an even incredible story that took us by surprise. 

God of has one of the most memorable stories and even most memorable characters, because it isn't afraid to tackle important issues, to focus on themes and to flesh out the essence of the characters. It starts a bonding journey between the worst father possible and a troubled BOY, but slowly and meaningfully it becomes something much more. Sure it has its moments of rapid action, destruction and mayhem, but in the end the charm of it is in the development of characters and how they relate to their goals and weaknesses, their virtues and passions.

A stunningly beautiful game with characters you grow to love. This is quite the adventure and I was 'all in' within a few minutes of starting. In the midst of Norse mythology, it is a sweet and heartwarming story about a father and a son building a relationship.

For me, it was a tough game, as I don't excel in combat. Thus, I played on the easiest setting which still was challenging.  There is no real penalty for death (just try again) and the explicit save system has dozens of slots.

The fights are relentless... monsters and spirits just keep showing up along your path and you do not have stealth options to avoid them.  I used 'brute-force' combat (charging forth with weapons blazing) and learned a new level of coordination with my keyboard and mouse to control special moves and runic attacks. In between encounters, there are environmental puzzles to solve, scenery to take in, and some tricky moves to open doors and chests. What a journey and I'm sorry to see it end!

You will do a fair bit of climbing and jumping but (at least in easy mode), you can't miss a jump or fall off an edge. This was much appreciated! 

Completionists will need to grind through two extra realms/areas that become accessible towards the end of the game.. Neither added anything to the story (in my opinion) and I slogged through both in search of the associated achievements.

The rest of the game is, in a word, spectacular! Great story, characters, voice acting, cinematics, etc. The game world is huge and diverse and you travel by foot, by boat and (ultimately) by fast travel through mystic gates. There are more collectibles than one can count and it pays to explore every corner of every environment. Resources abound and it was only at the end that I was short on rare items when I was trying to upgrade armor and weapons.

I can't say enough good things about God of War.  If you like 'big' game worlds with a captivating story, like Assassins Creed Origins or Horizon Zero Dawn, then this game is definitely something you will enjoy.
good to go

I have been a God of War fan since I was kid. Now I am 25 and having my own PC gamer was the perfect opportunity to play the new´s GOW. The experience was entertaining, amusing and a really good comeback of the series. The game experience is now a real challenge and you can easily die if you´re not careful enough, aside from that, the world itself invites you to explore and eventually grind in order to surpass any challenge that you may face. Maybe the combat can be a little monotonous at times and I also feel that only having one main antagonist feels a little... short? At least if we compare it to GOW 3, but hey, I assume that the developers wanted to throw all the meat in Ragnarok. Solid 8.5/10 and one of my best recent investments.

He sido un fan de God of War desde que era niño. Ahora que tengo 25 años y tengo mi propia PC gamer era la oportunidad perfecta para jugar los nuevos GOW. La experiencia fue entretenida y divertida y un gran regreso de la serie. La experiencia de juego ahora sí es un desafio y puedes morir fácilmente si no tienes el cuidado suficiente, y además de eso, el mundo en sí mismo te invita a explorar y eventualmente fortalecerte con tal de superar cualquier desafío al que te enfrentes. Quizás el combate en ocasiones puede sentirse monótono y también siento que solo tener un antagonista principal hace que el juego se sienta... ¿corto? Al menos si lo comparamos con GOW 3, pero hey, asumo que los desarrolladores querían tirar toda la carne al asador con Ragnarok. Sóliod 8.5/10 y una de las mejores inversiones que he hecho recientemente.

The gameplay is extremely simple and boring, but I'm not pissed about that.  If you want to know what kind of shit storm you're walking into on that front, go watch MatthewMatosis' God of War Case Study.

But the real problem, in this patented Sony walky-talky-semi-interactive movie, is the awful writing.  If anyone told you it was good, you can be certain that they didn't pay attention, they have abysmally low standards, or they are remarkably stupid.  Regardless of why someone might praise this game's writing, just know that they should not be listened to at all in the future.

This game has absurdly stupid dialogue.  You know that the idiots writing it really think they are being thoughtful, deep, and insightful, but they are, in fact, just idiots.

The dialogue is either extremely, painfully ham-fisted, or embarrassingly smug fourth-wall-bending high school sophistry peeking through a tattered veil of deliberate vaguery and butchered metaphors.

The characters are all idiots as well, and motivations are both paper thin and absolute.  This game is terrible.  People should not let this one sneak by as "a good story with some gameplay problems," because it is a stupid story, badly told, with terrible, boring gameplay.

God of war starts of strong telling a simple story between a father and his boy having to honour the last wish of the recently deceased mother of the family.

That wish being that her ashes are spread on the highest peak of all the realms, a simple journey on which Kratos gets to finally confront his son Atreus who’s education was mainly handled by his mother.

The game’s world rapidly expands as the player progressively takes in the state of this world and its lore. Personally I was expecting a linear story filled with confrontations against numerous norse gods but this is not really what God of War is about.

God of war is a bit of a semi open world which it gradually reveals after a dynamic start in the first third of the game. Things start to settle a bit and I began to slowly realise the scope of the game and the limits it actually contained.

What I thought was going to be one long epic journey filled with epic fights against mythical gods turned out to more so be an errand run around the lake of nine where one trinket after the next needs to usually be dug up to progress the main intrigue.

None the less God of War is an outstanding game with beautiful visuals and impressive sound design, it was the first time that a game ever made my jaw drop by its way of portraying gigantism as well through its visuals than through its sound design. 

The gameplay is very fun but after the two thirds of the game it grew stale for me, I do not believe the enemy variety was high enough to have kept me engaged and I am also not the type of person that found a lot of fun in many of the unlockable skills which mainly consist of additional combos or such rather than completely new abilities that might change your approach in combat.

I however do not doubt that if challenge is what you seek then a full knowledge of the entire combat possibilities that Kratos will dispose of throughout his journey will be necessary and rewarding to master.

The fact is that this is simply an amazing video game for which my expectations might have been a bit too ludicrous due to the high praise this experience gets. 

Although I did feel some disappointment in some regards I overall felt a lot of interest and excitement and those are the feelings I wish to remember the most out of my journey throughout the realms of Midgard.

I wholeheartedly recommend this experience and hope that you too may have an extremely pleasant time.

Before i start i must apoligise for any unclearlly used language or spelling mistakes on my part as i am dyslexic 15yo and English isn't my first language. Also i was inspired to make this review because of GamingWins and his '' Everthing great about God of War 2018'' video. I hope he doesn't mind that i used some of the things he says in his video. I really think you should check out the video and his channel as a whole, he has some great stuff.

As a long time player who has played throught The original trilogy, including Chains of Olympus, Ghost of Sparta, Ascension and even Betrayal + Mimir's Vision and i have listend to the God of War: The Lost Pages of Norse Myth podcast, I love the spin Cory Barlog has put on the franchise and i would even go out as far to say that this is possibly a top 2 game, excluding Ragnarok because i havent played it yet, the other one being God of War 3.

The God of War games have always been more towards re-imagening the mythologies meaning contrary to popular belief, the God of War franchise was not based on true facts and events that have happened in Greek and now Norse myth, When you think about it, there is no way that someone can travel from myth to myth because they can and not even Tyr. Actually Kratos, or how he was known in greek myth, Cratus or Cratos actually was one of the most trusted by Zeus and he never killed Ares, anyways this in an entirely other subject i won't get into right now. What i am trying to say is that inaccurate doesnt mean bad and as already stated i love the spin they put into this game.

This next part contais spoilers.

There are a few things that are left as ''plot holes'' such as Atreus being Loki. This would have been impossible as Loki is an Aesir god and we know that Faye is a giant and Kratos, well he is from a distand land, plus Loki often switches between being good and bad in myth where this isn't the case in the game. Another thing i would like to point out is that when you first go to the lake of nine, Atreus refers to Baldurs mother, which we find out later is the Vanir Goddess Freya, As Frigg. In Norse myth it is belived that frigg and Freya are possibly the same person (No on really knows as all evidance is unclear or lost to time). This is a ''plot hole'' because Atreus would just call her Freya, but it i don't know really. In this ''universe'' She might use both names interchangeably. These two are the main and really the only ones that i think are majour. 

Now that we got the criticism out of the way Lets get onto the things that made me fall in love with this game. Firstly I absolutelly love the world design as character design. The most important thing is that we See Kratos as more matued right away, but he is still ''draged down'' by his past mistakes. He turns away from his son as he wraps his bandage around his scars. This shows a much more mature Kratos, but he is still unable to forgive himself because he doesnt let go of his past. The bandage here is supossed to show how he is healing from his past, yet it only hurst him due to how he is unable to show the mistakes of his past and acts as a permenet chain that haunts him. (like the ones from the Blades of Chaos). And we later see how he becomes free of the pain as soon as he lets go of the bandage (chains). The second thing i absolutelly love about his is that he doesn't use any contreactions in his speach, which is so easy to do, yet makes him feel so much wiser. I also like how he grows as a father figure to Atreus. Kratos has never been there for his son and doesn't know how to be there for him for like half the game. The only parenting style he knows is the way of a Spartan warrior which is harsh, unforgiving and unpatiened. Kratos still knows this is wrong and later realises this isn't the way to go and starts truly to build a conection with his son (the moment i am referring to is as soon as Kratros steps out of the light of Alfheim). I will stop there, but there is so much more to talk about. I want to touch on the whole Baldur-Freya situation quickly. Baldur didn't realise that the need for vemgence is what caused his demise. To forgive is so much more about yourself than the other person, only if Baldur knew that, this wouldn't have happend and the death of this pantheon would have been prevented. YET AGAIN vengence leeds to the demise on YET another myth. I would talk about Baldur and Mangi, but they are pricks not worth talking about. They are seld-entitaled brats. The secont to last character i want to Talk about is Atreus/Loki. The part i think is most important is when he finds out he is a god and becomes a prick. This is important for the story as Kratos was scared to tell him the truth bacause he feared he would turn out like this. However Kratos managed to turn him around and make him good. This is where Kratos knew he should do everything he can to prevent the past from happening again. Last character is one who isn't present - Faye. Faye was the one who allowed for Baldur to enter the woods as she
marked the trees that she wanted Kratos to cut down. She knew that Kratros would think that Atreus wasn't ready so she marked the same trees that protected the woods. If it wasn't for her this journey would never have happened. Also Mimir is such a cool character that just makes this game so much more lively and gives us context that is important to the story. The world building and graphics.... ohhh don't get me started on the graphics. When you got that fuck-off sony money this is the AMAZING game you get.

Now for some of the small details that make we love this even more. When Kratos throws his Axe into the Lake of Nine and the World serpent returns it imbuded with Etir. Etir is the posion of the world serpent and the only thing that can kill Thor. If the axe is imbuded with it, it has the ability to kill Thor and This is why Kratos has the ability to kill him. I also love love how Thor is presented as A drunk and irresposible person which is actually true to the myth, contrasting our common missconception of him as A ''brave and fit hero''. 

This is my honest review of God of War 2018 after 130 hours played. Thank you if you read this and i hope you like and agree with my toughts. If I have used any wrong info, you are welcome to correct me in the comments.

I know a lot of people like this game, but I'll opt to play the devil's advocate on this one.  The game is stunning, has a compelling story, a rich lore and universe, yes.  The character's have personalities, yes.  But, really the combat is kind of clunky. Enemies have annoying abilities and I wound up throwing my axe a lot of the time because many enemies can dart in and out of melee range quickly and in seemingly unpredictable ways. It got frustrating after a while. Controls on PC seemed unnecessarily complex, and skill trees introduced new controls and abilities that were neat and impressive to look at, but felt rather gumpy in the context of actual combat. I would just panic and use my strongest ability. Such is fighting "AI" in every game I guess, they're usually just flighty and angry and rather boring to fight against.

I really enjoyed the first couple hours of the game, but that sweetness kind of wore off. Save your money unless you're very much into the excellent graphics, which are bar-none top 5 graphics of any game I've played!

Rating: ★★★★★ (5/5)

God of War, the 2018 reboot of the iconic series, is a transcendent gaming experience that spent 21.5 hours unearthing the depths of Norse mythology. This reinvention of Kratos and his journey is a tour de force in storytelling, gameplay, and emotional depth.

One of the most striking aspects of the game is its narrative. Kratos, the former Greek god of war, now embarks on a new adventure in the realm of Norse mythology, alongside his son, Atreus. The story is a masterfully woven tapestry of parenthood, redemption, and grappling with one's violent past. It's a journey that is as much about self-discovery as it is about gods and monsters.

The relationship between Kratos and Atreus is at the core of the narrative. It's a portrayal of fatherhood that is both poignant and deeply moving. The way the game explores the complexities of their bond, as well as the secrets of Kratos' past, makes it a storytelling triumph in the world of gaming.

Gameplay in God of War is a revelation. The game transitions from the traditional fixed camera and hack-and-slash combat of the original series to a more cinematic, over-the-shoulder perspective. The combat system is visceral and strategic, with a Leviathan Axe that can be thrown and recalled, as well as Atreus' ranged support, adding depth to the battles.

The world of God of War is a breathtaking and expansive rendition of Norse mythology. From the towering mountain of Midgard to the realms of Alfheim and Helheim, the game's environments are not just visually stunning but also integral to the narrative. The interconnectedness of the world creates a sense of immersion and adventure rarely seen in video games.

The attention to detail in God of War is staggering, both in the environment and the characters. The game's art and character design are a visual feast, and the voice acting is nothing short of exceptional. Christopher Judge's portrayal of Kratos and Sunny Suljic's performance as Atreus are particularly outstanding.

Throughout your 21.5-hour journey, you'll encounter challenging enemies and epic boss battles. The sense of accomplishment when overcoming these obstacles is immensely satisfying. God of War strikes a balance between accessibility for newcomers and depth for series veterans.

In conclusion, God of War is a monumental achievement in the world of gaming. The reboot takes a beloved character and reinvents him in a way that deepens the narrative and emotional resonance. With 21.5 hours of playtime, you've experienced the full breadth of the game's storytelling, gameplay, and breathtaking world. It stands as a testament to the potential of storytelling in video games, proving that they can be both emotionally gripping and artistically stunning. God of War is a journey that transcends its medium and is a must-play for anyone who appreciates the power of a well-crafted narrative in gaming.

I wholeheartedly recommend this game to people who have played the originals and newcomers to the saga alike.

 Kratos has evolved so much as a protagonist that he seemed like a completely different character at the beginning of this game. However, as you continue to play and learn about what has happened ever since we last saw him, you begin to realise that he has just grown as a person. A more mature, experienced, seasoned, wise, evolved Kratos is the protagonist that a story so emotional such as this one needs. The presence of young and sweet Atreus is a wonderful addition, he's just such a great companion and I don't only mean this from a story perspective, he was actually very useful in both combat and exploration as well. The game manages to hook you with its intriguing narrative and compelling characters that you end up liking a lot (shout-out to Mimir, Freya, and the world serpent, ilyall), while still having astonishing graphics and a really varied game-play, i.e., exploration, diverse combat systems and builds, plenty of different enemies and collectibles, side-quests, etc. 

 This third-person action-adventure is definitely a change from its prequels, but it doesn't mean something bad, it just means that it has adapted to today's trends. I am glad that this saga has been able to refurbish itself and is now thriving, it truly deserves to be as widely acclaimed as it has always been.
