**1. Narrative Depth:**
   The narrative intricacies of "God of War" are akin to a carefully woven tapestry. Kratos's journey, now set in the Norse realm, is a testament to the writers' commitment to character exploration. The game's opening, with the intimate funeral pyre scene, immediately establishes an emotional connection. The unfolding story, seamlessly blending Norse mythology with Kratos's personal odyssey, creates a narrative tapestry that is both epic and deeply personal.

**2. Character Development:**
   Kratos's evolution is not just a surface-level transformation; it's a profound metamorphosis. His struggles with the burden of his past and the challenge of guiding Atreus through a perilous world provide a depth rarely seen in gaming. Atreus, a pivotal character in his own right, grows from a curious boy to a vital companion. The nuanced interactions between father and son are scripted and performed with such authenticity that it elevates the emotional impact of the entire narrative.

**3. Visual Spectacle:**
   The visuals are a visual symphony. The game's use of the single-shot camera technique, a technical marvel, immerses players in the world without interruption. The attention to detail, from the subtle expressions on characters' faces to the dynamic weather systems, contributes to a level of realism that sets a new benchmark. Each realm, from the vibrant Alfheim to the desolate Helheim, showcases the artists' dedication to visual storytelling.

**4. Combat Excellence:**
   Combat in "God of War" is a choreographed dance of brutality and finesse. The Leviathan Axe, a weapon with its own narrative significance, feels weighty and responsive. The combat encounters are meticulously designed, requiring strategic thinking and adaptability. The progression system, with its array of skills and upgrades, empowers players to tailor Kratos's abilities to their preferred playstyle, adding a layer of personalization to the combat experience.

**5. Puzzles and Exploration:**
   The puzzles are not mere obstacles but integral parts of the narrative and world-building. They range from simple environmental puzzles to complex brain-teasers, seamlessly blending with the game's progression. Exploration is not just encouraged; it's rewarded with hidden chambers, lore-filled artifacts, and encounters that enrich the player's understanding of the Norse mythology underpinning the game.

**6. Sound Design and Music:**
   The sound design is a symphony of its own, capturing the crunch of Kratos's movements, the echoes of combat, and the ambient sounds of the mythical world. Bear McCreary's musical score is a masterclass, adapting to the emotional beats of the story. The use of a Nordic choir, singing in Old Norse, adds a layer of authenticity that enhances the immersive experience, making every moment more resonant.

**7. Metaphorical Depth:**
   Beyond the surface narrative, "God of War" is rife with metaphorical depth. The game explores themes of cyclical nature, the consequences of one's actions, and the interplay between fate and free will. The integration of mythological elements serves as a canvas for larger philosophical discussions, inviting players to reflect on their own journey within the game's narrative framework.

In essence, "God of War" earns its five-star rating through an unparalleled commitment to narrative, character, visual, and auditory excellence. Each element is not just a standalone feature but a crucial thread in the rich tapestry of gaming brilliance.

A very fun game that I regret putting off for so long. The story is rather short (you wont get a 40 hour story game here) but if you do the side quests between story missions you could end up close to that mark. I did not do any of the side quests other then hidden chests, but never felt under geared or didn't have enough money/xp sitting around. The combat is nice and fluid, and seems pretty stiff at first, but as you unlock ability's the combat becomes very fluid and fun. Worth a $30 sale price for sure.

Enjoyed the Growth of the Characters and the plot. Really immersive experience plus nice game mechanics.

[h1][b]Short review of God Of War[/b][/h1]

[h2][b]+[/b][/h2]
[b]• Plot.
• Graphics
• The atmosphere of ancient mythology.
• Combat
• Character development over time.
• An unusual protagonist.
• Lots of extra quests, narrating the game's lore.
• Variety of opponents.
• There is a new game + offering new challenges.
• Skill progression.[/b]

[h2][b]-[/b][/h2]
[b]• It's impossible to fall into the abyss
• The same type of kicking animations[/b]

[h2][b]Result[/b][/h2]
[b]God Of War is a terrific game with a great story, brutal combat and well-developed characters. I recommend playing this game.[/b]

This game is a good go to game for anyone who wants to be immersed into Greek and Norse mythology, or if anyone wants to be the god of war then this is the game for you! This is one of my most favorite games I have ever played, The graphics are amazing even on low so you don't have to worry about the game not looking good if you have a low end PC. This game has an amazing story line, The ending is amazing and it gives me hope that the PC version of god of war Ragnarok will be even better. If you can't buy the game don't worry you can always check out many You Tubers who have done entire lets-plays on this game so check those out as well.
